ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
City council member means any person who is an elected city official, including the mayor, of the City of Oakwood. 
Employee means any person who is a full-time or part-time employee of the City of Oakwood. 
Government or city means the government of the City of Oakwood, Georgia. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. II, § 1, 1-14-2008) 
Sec. 2-2. - Manager form of government. 
The city manager shall be vested with the authority and responsibility to oversee and supervise the regular business affairs of the city and shall act as the office manager of the city hall. Except as otherwise provided by general or local state law, he shall be the chief administrative officer of the city and shall exercise executive supervision over all city employees and departments. He shall further have such other duties as the mayor or council may require and which are not inconsistent with the ordinances of the city or any state law. The city manager need not be a resident of the city. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. VIII, § 1, 1-14-2008) 
State Law reference— Public officers and employees, O.C.G.A. § 45-2-1 et seq. 
Sec. 2-3. - Duties, responsibilities of city manager. 
(a)  The city manager shall be responsible for supervising all paid employees of the city other than the city attorney and the city judge. The city manager's authority to supervise employees under his control shall include the ability to hire, discipline or dismiss any such employee. The city manager shall be responsible for the supervision and control of the chief of police and all employees reporting to the chief of police. The chief of police, subject to the approval and supervision of the city manager, shall be responsible for the hiring, firing and supervision of all police department employees and shall have the ability to take disciplinary action against any employee of the police department. 
(b)  The city manager shall have the authority to adopt and implement personnel policies and procedures for the orderly administration of personnel matters within the city which shall apply to all employees under the control of the city manager. The chief of police shall have the authority, with the approval of the city manager, to adopt and implement standard operating procedures and personnel policies for the orderly administration of personnel matters in the police department. The city manager and the chief of police shall not adopt or implement any personnel policies pursuant to the authority granted in this section which would have the effect of changing the status of any employee of the city to any designation other than an employee at will. In addition, no personnel policies or procedures shall be adopted by the manager or the chief of police pursuant to the authority granted in this section which would limit or prohibit the mayor and city council from exercising the legal authority granted to the mayor and city council pursuant to article 3 of the Charter, which authorizes the mayor and council to exercise ultimate final authority over the administrative affairs of the city. This specifically shall preclude policies or procedures (written or otherwise) which limit or reduce the authority of the mayor to inquire and investigate the conduct of city affairs. 
(c)  The city manager shall have such other and further duties, responsibilities and authority as may be delegated to the city manager by the mayor and council. The city manager shall be responsible for overseeing and supervising the regular business affairs of the city and shall report directly to the mayor and council. 
(d)  The city manager shall be appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the city council. The compensation, benefits, term of office and other conditions of employment of the city manager shall be established by the mayor and council and set forth in an employment contract. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. VIII, § 2, 1-14-2008) 
Sec. 2-4. - Oath of office. 
Pursuant to section 2.14(d) of the city Charter, no member of any board, commission or authority shall assume office until he shall have executed and filed with the city clerk an oath obligating himself to faithfully and impartially perform the duties of his office as prescribed hereinafter and administered by the mayor as follows: 
"I do solemnly swear or affirm that I will faithfully execute the office of [member of board, commission or authority as the case may be] of the City of Oakwood and will to the best of my ability support and defend the Constitution of the United States, the Constitution of Georgia and the Charter, ordinances and regulations of the City of Oakwood. I am not the holder of any unaccounted for public money due this state or any political subdivision or authority thereof. I am not the holder of any office of trust under the government of the United States, any other state or any foreign state which I, by the laws of the State of Georgia, am prohibited from holding. I am otherwise qualified to hold said office according to the Constitution and laws of Georgia. [I have been a resident of the City of Oakwood for the time required by the Constitution and laws of this state and by the municipal charter of the City of Oakwood.*] I will perform the duties of my office in the best interest of the City of Oakwood to the best of my ability without fear, favor, affection, reward or expectation thereof." 
(*If applicable) 
(Ord. No. 554, § 2, 5-12-2008) 
State Law reference— Oath of office, O.C.G.A. § 45-3-1 et seq. 
Sec. 2-5. - Mayor and city council member salaries. 
The annual salary of the mayor of the city is hereby increased from $5,400.00 a year to $10,800.00 a year ($900.00 per month) and the salary of each member of the city council is hereby increased from $4,200.00 per year to $7,200.00 a year ($600.00 per month). Said increase is pursuant to and authorized by the city Charter and O.C.G.A. § 36-35-4. 
(Ord. No. 134, § 1, 10-15-1985; Ord. No. 232, § 1, 2-13-1995; Ord. No. 554, art. VI, § 1, 1-14-2008) 
State Law reference— Salary of municipal employees, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-4. 
Sec. 2-6. - Per diem pay. 
The mayor and members of the city council shall be entitled to a per diem pay of $50.00 per meeting (maximum of ten meetings per month) for attendance at meetings other than regular and special meetings of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 646, § 2, 11-9-2009) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 646, § 2, adopted Nov. 9, 2009, deleted § 2-6 in its entirety and enacted new provisions to read as herein set out. Prior to amendment, § 2-6 pertained to similar subject matter. See Code Comparative Table. 
Sec. 2-7. - Travel reimbursement for elected officials. 
(a)  Adoption; purpose. Pursuant to the authority granted to it by the laws of the state and the city Charter, the city council hereby ordains that the following policy is adopted to compensate and reimburse city elected officials who will be traveling for approved city business. Elected officials are encouraged to take advantage of training opportunities and represent the city at various meetings and events. This travel policy is hereby established to facilitate reimbursement for expenses incurred. Elected officials are responsible to know what the city's travel policy states and to abide by this policy. Elected officials shall only be reimbursed for expenses actually and necessarily incurred by the elected official in carrying out their official duties. No reimbursement shall ever exceed the actual expenditure incurred by the elected official. 
(b)  Meetings; events; out-of-state travel. Any elected official's attendance or travel to training, meetings, or events held out of state that is not related to the Georgia Municipal Association (GMA) or National League of Cities (NLC) must be pre-approved by the city council. 
(c)  Spouse/dependent attendance. Within budget, the city encourages elected officials to attend functions that will be in the best interest of the city. Spousal attendance frequently enhances the image of the city and is usually encouraged. However, the city cannot expend public funds for spouses while elected officials are attending meetings, conferences, training sessions, conventions or other city-sponsored functions. Therefore, spousal attendance/participation is a personal expense. 
(d)  Expenses. 
(1)  Accommodations. 
a.  Outside a 50-mile radius. The city will pay for overnight lodging expenses outside the 50-mile radius of the city for training. Accommodations should be in or as close to the conference center as possible. 
1.  Room receipts are required. Amounts are expected to be reasonable and within the range of similar quarters in the immediate area visited, not to exceed an amount equal to established convention rates at the convention/meeting headquarters hotel. If accommodations are not available at the headquarters hotel, the city will pay the prevailing rate at alternate hotels recommended by the convention officials, not to exceed the rate of the headquarters hotel. 
2.  The city is exempted from all taxes when its officials stay in a hotel in the state. A hotel/motel tax exemption form and a state tax exemption form will be provided for the elected official to present upon arriving at the hotel. 
3.  Officials must pick up a city check or city credit card before leaving for the trip and present at check-in for each overnight in-state trip, (required) to receive tax exemptions. It is the responsibility of the elected official to ensure that all tax exemptions are secured; the city will not reimburse for tax that should have been exempted. 
b.  Within a 50-mile radius. The city will not pay/reimburse for overnight lodging expenses within a 50-mile radius of the city, unless pre-approved by council for circumstances where an elected official may have early morning or late night meetings. 
1.  The approval should be confirmed in advance of registration to stay at a convention hotel within the 50-mile radius. 
2.  The city will cover overnight lodging expenses within a 50-mile radius when a city strategic planning conference is held and the city will pay directly to the facility. Mileage expenses may be reimbursed for strategic conferences, using city hall as the beginning point, since reimbursement policies normally do not cover mileage getting to the place of work. 
(2)  Food. Travelers are expected to take advantage of all meals included in convention/meeting registration fees. Expenses for other meals shall be paid based on a reasonable food cost in the area being visited. 
a.  The city will not pay for alcoholic beverages. Spouses or guest's meals (including tax and gratuities) and/or any alcoholic beverages must be deducted from receipts; only travelers' expenses may be included on the reimbursement request. 
b.  Tips shall not exceed 15 percent of the total bill. 
(3)  Transportation. Travel reimbursements will cover either commercial tickets (usually airline) or mileage for use of a personal vehicle at the rate as allowed by the IRS and approved by the city council. Reimbursements will not be made for first-class commercial airline tickets. The city will reimburse for the most cost-effective mode of travel. 
a.  Reasonable taxi fares and parking fees are covered when necessary. 
b.  All personal vehicle mileage must be substantiated with a detailed listing including beginning and ending odometer reading, total miles driven and the purpose of the meeting/trip. Expense reports without this documentation will be returned to the requestor (without payment) for explanation. 
(e)  Reimbursements. Proper documentation is always needed for expenses to be paid by the city. The main items for proper documentation consist of receipts, meeting agenda, outline of meals by day and by meal, and detailed explanation of any item reported that is not ordinary in nature. Transactions and payments with respect to lodging, travel, and the credit card are managed and approved by the city clerk's office. 
(1)  When all proper documentation is attached to the travel voucher, it should be turned in to the city clerk, who will review the voucher and the appropriate backup for any irregularities. The clerk will then obtain one other approval from another elected official and submit to the accounting department for payment. If an irregularity exists, the city clerk will address the issue immediately. If extenuating circumstances occur, then each situation will be reviewed on a case-by-case basis. 
(2)  To support claims for travel and extra expenses following out-of-town events, an expense report must be submitted (see attachment 1, which is not set out herein but is on file and available for inspection in the office of the city clerk) and receipts must be turned in for reimbursement within three business days after returning from a trip. Elected officials may only be reimbursed for expenses actually and necessarily incurred in carrying out their official duties. Other necessary or unusual expenses incurred will be paid after written explanation is attached to travel voucher and approved by all appropriate personnel. 
(3)  Telephone charges are allowed so the employee can call home. The employee is allowed one phone call home each day with the charges not to exceed $8.00 per day. Local phone charges (usually $0.75) are allowed unless they become excessive. 
(4)  Reimbursements will be made on a priority basis. The business office will return checks to the travelers within five working days. 
(f)  Exclusions. 
(1)  Entertainment expenses. The city will not pay for any movies or other entertainment expenses while traveling. 
(2)  Sports activities. The city will not pay any fees for sports activities associated with tournaments, etc. Even if some of the activities are a part of the conference agenda, the officials must pay the cost to participate. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. VI, § 3, 1-14-2008) 
Sec. 2-8. - Employee travel reimbursement. 
Employees will be reimbursed for travel expenses while on city business as follows: 
(1)  Private vehicle use. Reimbursement for private vehicle use shall be adjusted annually to conform to the mileage rate established by the IRS. 
(2)  Meals/incidentals. Reimbursement for meals and incidentals shall be adjusted annually to conform to the locality per diem rates established by the U.S. General Services Administration. 
(3)  Lodging. Reimbursement for lodging shall be the actual reasonable cost approved in advance by the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. VI, § 4, 1-14-2008) 
Sec. 2-9. - Employee benefits. 
The city shall make available to employees the benefits as set forth in the personnel policies. The employee compensation plan shall be recommended annually by the city manager as a part of the budget process. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. VII, § 1, 1-14-2008) 
State Law reference— Authority to provide compensation and employee benefits to municipal officers and employees, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-4. 
Secs. 2-10—2-36. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CITY COUNCIL RULES OF PROCEDURE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Public officers and employees, O.C.G.A. § 45-2-1 et seq.; open meetings, O.C.G.A. § 50-14-1; exemptions from open meeting requirements, O.C.G.A. § 50-14-3. 

Sec. 2-37. - Meeting times; place; notice. 
(a)  Regular meetings of the city council shall be on the second Monday of each month beginning at 7:00 p.m., pursuant to section 2.09(c) of the Charter. 
(b)  Regular meetings of the city council shall convene in the assembly room of city hall. 
(c)  Special meetings of the city council shall be called in accordance with section 2.13(d) of the city Charter. If the place where any such special meeting is to convene shall be at any place other than the place specified in subsection (b) of this section, then the notice shall so specify. Subject to O.C.G.A. § 50-14-1(d), special meetings may be held at any time without notice to all councilmembers upon attendance at such meeting by all members of the council or by waiving of notice by those not in attendance. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. IV, § 1, 1-14-2008) 
State Law reference— Notice of meetings, O.C.G.A. § 50-14-1. 
Sec. 2-38. - Open meetings. 
Except for those exceptions specifically provided for by general law, all meetings of the city council shall be open to the public. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. IV, § 2, 1-14-2008) 
State Law reference— Open meetings, O.C.G.A. § 50-14-1. 
Sec. 2-39. - Quorum. 
Quorum requirements shall be as specified in section 2.10 of the Charter. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. IV, § 3, 1-14-2008) 
Sec. 2-40. - Agenda. 
(a)  The mayor shall have the power and duty to set the agenda after receiving input from members of the city council, the city manager and the public for meetings of the city council, pursuant to section 3.01(11) of the Charter. 
(b)  The agenda for each regular meeting (and work session) of the city council shall be prepared and distributed to the members of the city council no later than the preceding Friday. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. IV, § 4, 1-14-2008) 
State Law reference— Meeting agenda required, O.C.G.A. § 50-14-1. 
Sec. 2-41. - Public hearing procedure on general matters. 
The public hearing procedure on general matters shall be as follows: 
(1)  The presiding officer opens the public hearing. 
(2)  Staff summarizes the public hearing procedures which are as follows: 
a.  Staff will present the item. 
b.  The petitioner will then have the opportunity to present his request. 
c.  Those who support the application will be asked to comment first. 
d.  Those who oppose the application or who have questions will be asked to comment next. 
e.  The petitioner will then have an opportunity to make summary remarks and answer any questions raised by the public. 
f.  After the petitioner's summary remarks, the public hearing will be closed. 
g.  After the public hearing is closed, the council will consider the items presented. At that time, the council may discuss the item, and call upon the petitioner or other interested parties to clarify points and answer questions. Additional questions or comments from the public may not be asked once the public hearing has been closed. 
(3)  All parties wishing to speak during the public hearing should come to the podium, give their name, address and interest along with any comments they may have on the item. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. IV, § 5, 1-14-2008) 
Sec. 2-42. - Public hearing procedure on zoning matters. 
The public hearing procedure on zoning matters shall be as follows: 
(1)  Proposed amendments to the zoning ordinance may be introduced for first reading at any regular or special meeting of the city council. 
(2)  Proposed amendments to the zoning ordinance shall be disposed of by the receipt of public input, item by item. At the close of public input and as part of new business, the city council shall take up the consideration of each such item as follows: 
a.  If a parcel is to be annexed into the city, the agenda shall reflect a separate item for consideration of annexation only first. Immediately upon acceptance of the parcel for annexation, the chair shall cause the caption of the annexation ordinance to be read followed by a vote on the questions of accepting said ordinance for first reading. 
b.  A separate agenda item shall identify the current zoning of the property and the proposed zoning classification along with the purpose of the zoning change. 
(3)  During the public hearing, all persons supporting and opposing a proposed rezoning may take either one of two different opportunities to address the mayor and city council on the proposed rezoning, as follows: 
a.  Ten-minute argument opportunity. 
1.  Proponents shall first present their ten-minute argument in support of the proposed rezoning and opponents shall then present their ten-minute argument in opposition to the proposed rezoning. 
2.  Neither side will be required to use all of its ten-minute argument period. 
3.  Either side may allocate its ten-minute argument period among any number of speakers, provided that the presentation by all speakers for each side shall not exceed ten minutes per side. 
4.  All persons wishing to speak longer than three minutes during one side's ten-minute argument period must register their intent to do so with the city clerk not later than the time that the meeting of the mayor and city council at which the public hearing on the proposed rezoning is to be conducted is first called to order. 
5.  In the event that all persons wishing to speak longer than three minutes as a part of one side's ten-minute argument are not able to agree how that side's ten-minute argument period shall be allocated, they shall inform the mayor of their disagreement before either side begins its ten-minute argument, in which event the mayor shall decide and announce the manner in which that side's ten-minute argument period shall be allocated. Any councilmember dissatisfied with the mayor's allocation of that side's ten-minute argument shall have the right to appeal the mayor's allocation decision to the city council before either side begins its ten-minute argument for a decision by the city council. 
b.  After the proponents and opponents of the proposed rezoning have concluded their ten-minute arguments, any person who has not yet spoken either for or against the proposed rezoning shall be allowed to address the mayor and city council concerning the proposed rezoning for no longer than one minute per person. Such person shall identify themselves along with their address upon being recognized by the chair. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. IV, § 6, 1-14-2008) 
State Law reference— Notice and hearing on zoning matters, O.C.G.A. § 36-66-4. 
Sec. 2-43. - Public input. 
Except as specifically provided for in section 2-42 for zoning matters, at such point in the city council's agenda when the city council is receiving public input from citizens and others, the following rules shall apply: 
(1)  All oral public input shall be received before the city council undertakes the consideration or disposition of any matter. The mayor shall first invite the public input as to any item appearing on the city council agenda and shall then invite the public input as to any matter not on the city council's agenda. 
(2)  Throughout the time that the city council is receiving public input, neither the mayor nor any city council member shall interrupt, question or otherwise engage in any kind of debate with such person. 
(3)  Public input shall be limited to three minutes per person with notice of 30 seconds remaining. 
(4)  Any member of the public who, with the intent to prevent or disrupt the meeting, substantially obstructs or interferes with the meeting by physical action or verbal utterance shall be removed from the meeting at the direction of the mayor. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. IV, § 7, 1-14-2008) 
State Law reference— Notice and hearing on zoning matters, O.C.G.A. § 36-66-4. 
Sec. 2-44. - Schedule for consideration and final action. 
All matters calling for action by the city council shall be introduced, considered and disposed of as follows: 
(1)  No ordinance shall be considered for final disposition unless it shall have first been considered in the course of at least one prior meeting of the city council in accordance with section 2.15(a) of the Charter. 
(2)  When a matters is before the city council for consideration for final disposition, no motion shall be received but: 
a.  To adjourn; 
b.  To lay on the table; 
c.  To pass out with no action; 
d.  For the previous question; 
e.  To postpone indefinitely; 
f.  To postpone to a day certain; 
g.  To commit; or 
h.  To amend; 
which several motions shall have precedence in the order listed. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. IV, § 8, 1-14-2008) 
Sec. 2-45. - Consent agenda. 
(a)  As a part of the agenda for any meeting of the city council, the mayor may set forth those items of a routine nature calling for action by the city council and as to which it is anticipated that their consideration and disposition will not require any significant discussion by the members of the city council. 
(b)  Upon the objection of any councilmember to any one or more of such items remaining on the consent agenda, the same shall be removed therefrom and assigned an item number and taken up individually, later in the meeting, and the city council shall proceed to consider the remainder of the items on the first part of the consent agenda. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. IV, § 9, 1-14-2008) 
Sec. 2-46. - Motion for the previous question. 
(a)  The motion for the previous question shall only be admitted when demanded by a majority of the city council voting and on the motion for the previous question there shall be no debate. 
(b)  The motion for the previous question shall take precedence over all other motions except a motion to adjourn or to lay on the table and, when it is moved, the first question shall be: "Shall the motion for the previous question be sustained?" 
(c)  If decided in the affirmative, the city council shall then proceed to act on the previous question. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. IV, § 10, 1-14-2008) 
Sec. 2-47. - Stating the question. 
The mayor shall state all questions to the city council and declare the vote thereon in accordance with section 2-64. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. IV, § 11, 1-14-2008) 
Sec. 2-48. - Division of a question. 
When a motion, resolution, ordinance or other matter relating to a certain subject contains several parts, each of which is capable of standing as a complete proposition if the others are removed, it may be divided into two or more propositions to be considered and voted on as distinct questions. Any city council member may move for a division of the question on a subject in which the sense thereof will admit it. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. IV, § 12, 1-14-2008) 
Sec. 2-49. - Motion to reconsider. 
(a)  Before the minutes of the preceding meeting of the city council shall be read or approved without reading, any member of the prevailing side on a matter previously disposed of may move for a reconsideration of any matter therein contained except such as has already been the subject of a motion to reconsider. 
(b)  Motions for reconsideration of a matter shall be made and voted on no later than at the meeting following the meeting at which the matter was decided and shall be made before the minutes of said previous meeting are approved. However, actions on an amendment to any pending matter may be reconsidered at any time before the final action on the ordinance, resolution or other matter to which the amendment relates. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. IV, § 13, 1-14-2008) 
Sec. 2-50. - Call from table. 
A majority of the city council members may call up for consideration any matter ordered to lie on the table. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. IV, § 14, 1-14-2008) 
Sec. 2-51. - When matters in possession of the city council. 
When an ordinance, resolution, motion or other matter is introduced before the city council and stated by the mayor, or read by the city clerk, it shall be deemed to be in the possession of the city council and may not be withdrawn at any time before the final disposition thereof without the consent of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. IV, § 15, 1-14-2008) 
Sec. 2-52. - Matters previously rejected. 
(a)  Whenever any matter or proposal has been rejected by the city council, it shall not be introduced or considered again during the calendar year during which the rejection occurred except on motion to reconsider made pursuant to section 2-49. 
(b)  Any matter subject to a no-action decision by the city council may be brought back to the city council at any time. 
(c)  Exempted from the provisions of this section shall be any matters brought to the city council by the city board of planning and zoning in accordance with its rules and procedures. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. IV, § 16, 1-14-2008) 
Sec. 2-53. - Motion to adjourn. 
A motion to adjourn shall always be in order in meetings of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. IV, § 17, 1-14-2008) 
Sec. 2-54. - Mayor to preserve order. 
The mayor shall preserve order in meetings of the city council and shall, in the exercise of a sound discretion, suspend irrelevant debate and command silence, whenever the same may be deemed needed. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. IV, § 18, 1-14-2008) 
Sec. 2-55. - Mayor may call councilmembers or city attorney to chair. 
The mayor may, during any meeting of the city council, call the mayor pro tempore, or in the event that the mayor pro tempore is not present, name any member of the city council, to perform the duties of the chair during any part of that meeting but no longer. The mayor may also call the city attorney to perform the duties of the chair in any public hearing of a matter. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. IV, § 19, 1-14-2008) 
Sec. 2-56. - Address to be through the chair. 
No member of the city council shall address the city council or interrogate a member who is speaking except through the chair. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. IV, § 20, 1-14-2008) 
Sec. 2-57. - Who is entitled to floor. 
Councilmembers shall be recognized in the order in which recognition is sought. When two or more councilmembers shall seek recognition at the same time, the mayor shall name the person entitled to proceed. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. IV, § 21, 1-14-2008) 
Sec. 2-58. - Debate. 
When any councilmember is about to speak in debate or deliver any matter to the city council, the member shall respectfully address the chair, shall be confined to the matter in debate and shall not speak more than three times on any subject and no more than five minutes per address with notice of 30 seconds remaining. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. IV, § 22, 1-14-2008) 
Sec. 2-59. - Silence. 
The members of the city council shall forbear from private conversation and preserve silence until a speaking member shall have yielded the floor. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. IV, § 23, 1-14-2008) 
Sec. 2-60. - Decorum. 
If any member transgresses the rules of the city council, in speaking or otherwise, the mayor may call the member to order, in which case the member so called to order shall immediately yield the floor unless permitted to explain. If appealed to the chair, the city council shall decide. If the decision of the city council is not then submitted to, the delinquent member shall, for the first offense, be reproved, and, for continuing refractory, may be expelled from the city council chamber. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. IV, § 24, 1-14-2008) 
Sec. 2-61. - Attorney's opinion. 
(a)  It shall be in order, in the course of a meeting of the city council, or of any committee thereof, for the city attorney to make recommendations on matters before the city council, to introduce matters for the city council's consideration or propose matters for referral to committee. 
(b)  Upon a vote of the city council so directing, the city attorney shall furnish the city clerk with a copy of any opinion given by the city attorney concerning the city council or any department, board, commission or authority of the city and such written opinion may be required to be rendered prior to the next regular meeting of the city council and made a part of the records of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. IV, § 25, 1-14-2008) 
Sec. 2-62. - Rulings upon points of order. 
The mayor shall decide all points of order but an appeal may be had from any such decision to the city council. When requested, either by the mayor or by any councilmember, the city attorney shall act as parliamentarian and shall render an opinion to the mayor on any point of order. A vote of two-thirds of the city council present shall be necessary to override a decision of the mayor on a point of order. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. IV, § 26, 1-14-2008) 
Sec. 2-63. - Suspending the rules. 
These rules shall in no case be suspended nor shall the order of business be changed except by a vote of three-fourths of the city council members voting. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. IV, § 27, 1-14-2008) 
Sec. 2-64. - All votes recorded. 
All votes on all matters shall be recorded and, unless the same shall be unanimous, the same shall be contingent upon the recording of the "ayes" and "nays" of each councilmember, the names of those abstaining and those absent, all of which shall be entered upon the minutes of the proceedings of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. IV, § 28, 1-14-2008) 
Sec. 2-65. - Minutes. 
(a)  The city clerk shall prepare the proposed minutes of the meetings of the city council and shall keep and maintain the minutes and records of all meetings of the city council. The city clerk shall keep and maintain any other records or recordings of the meetings of the city council in such manner and for such time as the city council shall require. Any citizen shall have access to the minutes and records of the city council once approved at reasonable times. 
(b)  Following regular and special called sessions of the city council, the city clerk shall provide the mayor and each councilmember a copy of the proposed minutes of the meeting no later than Friday preceding the next regular meeting. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. IV, § 29, 1-14-2008) 
Sec. 2-66. - Parliamentary rules. 
When any question arises, in a meeting of the city council, which is not provided for in these rules, the same, so far as practicable, shall be controlled by the rules and usages usually governing parliamentary bodies as set forth in Robert's Rules of Order, latest edition. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. IV, § 30, 1-14-2008) 
Sec. 2-67. - Rules and procedures. 
The rules and procedures for meetings before any of the several city boards, commissions and authorities shall be in accordance with the rules and procedures adopted in this article with the following exceptions and additions: 
(1)  The chair of such board, commission or authority shall perform the duties and obligations ascribed to the mayor in this article. 
(2)  Matters forwarded for consideration by the city council shall be accompanied by that portion of the minutes of the meeting in which the matter was considered (or a draft thereof if formal approval of such minutes has not been made). 
(3)  Each board, commission and authority of the city shall follow the within rules and procedures except to the extent that such rules and procedures conflict with the city Charter or the enabling ordinance or legislation for such board, commission or authority. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. V, § 1, 1-14-2008; Amd. No. 554, § 1, 5-12-2008) 
Sec. 2-68. - Oath of office. 
Pursuant to section 2.14(d) of the Charter, no member of any board, commission or authority shall assume office until he shall have executed and filed with the city clerk an oath obligating himself to faithfully and impartially perform the duties of his office as prescribed hereinafter and administered by the mayor as follows: 
"I do solemnly swear or affirm that I will faithfully execute the office of [member of board, commission or authority as the case may be] of the City of Oakwood and will to the best of my ability support and defend the Constitution of the United States, the Constitution of Georgia and the Charter, ordinances and regulations of the City of Oakwood. I am not the holder of any unaccounted for public money due this state or any political subdivision or authority thereof. I am not the holder of any office of trust under the government of the United States, any other state or any foreign state which I, by the laws of the State of Georgia, am prohibited from holding. I am otherwise qualified to hold said office according to the Constitution and laws of Georgia. [I have been a resident of the City of Oakwood for the time required by the Constitution and laws of this state and by the municipal charter of the City of Oakwood.*] I will perform the duties of my office in the best interest of the City of Oakwood to the best of my ability without fear, favor, affection, reward or expectation thereof." 
(*If applicable) 
(Ord. No. 554, art. V, § 1, 1-14-2008; Amd. No. 554, art. V, § 2, 6-9-2008) 
Secs. 2-69—2-94. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BOARDS, COMMISSIONS AND COMMITTEES 

Sec. 2-95. - Membership. 
The city planning commission shall consist of five members, each of which shall be residents of the city, appointed by the mayor of the city. The terms of the members shall be for four years, except that in the appointment of the first city planning commission under the terms of this article, one of the members shall be appointed for a term of one year, one for a term of two years, one for a term of three years, and two for a term of four years. Any vacancy in membership shall be filled for the unexpired term by the mayor who shall also have the authoring to remove any city-appointed member for cause, on written charges, after a public hearing. 
(Ord. No. 45, § 1, 12-12-1977; Ord. No. 2016-CO-05-740, § 1, 5-16-2016) 
Sec. 2-96. - Organization, rules, staff and finances. 
The city planning commission shall elect its chairperson from among its members. The term of the chairperson shall be one year with eligibility for reelection. The planning commission shall appoint a secretary who may be an officer or an employee of the municipality. The planning commission shall make its own rules of meetings and determining its time of meeting. All meetings of the planning commission at which official action is taken shall be open to the public and all records of the planning commission shall be a public record. The planning commission may appoint such employees and staff as it may deem necessary for its work and may contract with the state planning agency and with the city planners and other consultants for such services as it may require. The expenditures of the planning commission, exclusive of gifts, shall be within the amounts appropriated for the purpose by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 45, § 2, 12-12-1977) 
Sec. 2-97. - Powers and duties. 
From and after the time when the planning commission shall have organized and selected its officers, and shall have adopted its rules of procedure, then said planning commission shall have all the powers, duties and responsibilities set forth in the General Planning and Zoning Enabling Act of 1957. (Act No. 353, as amended.) 
(Ord. No. 45, § 3, 12-12-1977) 
Sec. 2-98. - [Compensation.] 
Members of all boards, commissions and committees of the City of Oakwood shall serve without compensation but shall be entitled to receive reimbursement for expenses incurred in connection with their official duties. For all meetings which occur within Hall County, Georgia, each member shall receive a per diem for each meeting attended in an amount equal to the per diem for city officials set forth in section 2-6 of the Oakwood City Code. For approved travel outside of Hall County, Georgia, travel reimbursement shall be as set forth in section 2-7 of the Oakwood City Code. 
(Ord. No. 2016-CO-05-740, § 2, 5-16-2016) 
Secs. 2-99—2-122. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - ETHICS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Ethics in Government Act, O.C.G.A. § 21-5-1 et seq. 

Sec. 2-123. - Intent. 
It is the intent of this section that city council members avoid any action whether or not specifically prohibited by section 2-124 which might result in or create the appearance of the following: 
(1)  Using public office for private gain; 
(2)  Impeding government efficiency or economy; or 
(3)  Affecting adversely the confidence of the public in the integrity of the government. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. II, § 3, 1-14-2008) 
Sec. 2-124. - Acceptance of gifts. 
(a)  City council members shall not solicit or accept directly or indirectly anything of value from any person, corporation or group which: 
(1)  Has or is seeking to obtain contractual or other business or financial relationships with the city; 
(2)  In exchange for the thing of value, seeks to have a councilmember exercise a matter of discretion in his favor; 
(3)  In exchange for the thing of value, seeks to have interests which may be affected by the performance or nonperformance of the official duty of the councilmember. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to campaign contributions which shall be reported in accordance with state law. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. II, § 2, 1-14-2008) 
Sec. 2-125. - Financial interests of members. 
The city council members may not: 
(1)  Have direct or indirect financial interests that conflict substantially with their responsibilities and duties as government servants; or 
(2)  Engage in, directly or indirectly, financial transactions as a result of, or primarily relying upon, information obtained from their office. Aside from these restrictions, city council members are free to engage in lawful financial transactions to the same extent as private citizens. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. II, § 4, 1-14-2008) 
State Law reference— Voting when personally interested, O.C.G.A. § 36-30-6. 
Sec. 2-126. - Use of public property. 
A city council member shall not use government property of any kind for other than officially approved activities nor shall he direct employees to use such property for these purposes. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. II, § 5, 1-14-2008) 
Sec. 2-127. - Use of confidential information. 
A city council member shall not directly or indirectly make use of, or permit others to make use of, for the purpose of furthering a private interest, official information not made available to the general public. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. II, § 6, 1-14-2008) 
Sec. 2-128. - Coercion by councilmembers. 
A city council member shall not use his position in any way to coerce, or give the appearance of coercing, another person to provide any financial benefit to him or persons within his immediate family or those with whom a councilmember has business or financial ties. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. II, § 7, 1-14-2008) 
Sec. 2-129. - Voting in matters of personal interest. 
A city council member shall not vote on an ordinance or amendment in a city council meeting that would directly affect his private business. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. II, § 8, 1-14-2008) 
State Law reference— Voting when personally interested, O.C.G.A. § 36-30-6. 
Sec. 2-130. - Unauthorized purchases. 
A city council member shall not order any goods and services for the city without prior official authorization for such expenditure. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. II, § 9, 1-14-2008) 
Sec. 2-131. - City attorneys used for private business. 
A city council member shall not use the attorneys who are under retainer by the city for personal or private business without paying just compensation. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. II, § 10, 1-14-2008) 
Sec. 2-132. - Unauthorized use of public employees. 
A city council member shall not use his superior position to request or require an employee to: 
(1)  Do clerical work on behalf of his family, business, social, church or fraternal interests; 
(2)  Purchase goods and services to be used for personal, business or political purposes; or 
(3)  Work for him personally without offering just compensation. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. II, § 11, 1-14-2008) 
Sec. 2-133. - Travel expenses. 
A city council member shall not draw per diem or expense monies from the city to attend a seminar, convention or conference and then fail to attend the seminar, convention or conference without refunding the pro rata unused per diem or expense monies to the city. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. II, § 12, 1-14-2008) 
Sec. 2-134. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2010-CO-01-654, § 1, adopted Feb. 8, 2010, deleted § 2-134 in its entirety. Former § 2-134 pertained to penalties. See Code Comparative Table for derivation. 
Sec. 2-135. - Board of ethics. 
(a)  Composition of the board of ethics: 
(1)  The board of ethics of the city shall be composed of three residents of the city to be appointed as provided in subsections (a)(2) and (3) of this section. Each member of the board of ethics shall have been a resident of the city for at least one year immediately preceding the date of taking office and shall remain a resident of the city while serving as a member of the board of ethics. No person shall serve as a member of the board of ethics if the person has, or has had within the preceding one-year period, any interest in any contract, transaction or official action of the city. 
(2)  The mayor and councilmembers shall each designate one qualified citizen to provide a pool of six individuals who have consented to serve as a member of such board of ethics and who will be available for a period of two years to be called upon to serve in the event a board of ethics is appointed. 
(3)  The city manager shall maintain a listing of these six qualified citizens. Should the investigating committee determine a complaint warrants a hearing before the board of ethics, the mayor and council, at the first public meeting after such determination, shall draw names randomly from the listing of qualified citizens until the specified three members of the board of ethics have been appointed. Such board of ethics will elect one of its members to serve as chairperson. The city attorney shall serve as an ex officio member. 
(4)  The members of the board of ethics shall serve without compensation. The city manager shall provide meeting space for the board of ethics. Subject to budgetary procedures and requirements of the city, the city shall provide the board of ethics with such supplies and equipment as may be reasonably necessary for it to perform its duties and responsibilities. 
(b)  The constituted board of ethics shall have the following duties and powers: 
(1)  To establish procedures, rules and regulations governing its internal organization and conduct of its affairs; 
(2)  To hold a hearing within 60 days after the receipt of the complaint. Failure to hold a hearing within the specified time shall result in dismissal of the complaint as to the transaction and shall prevent refiling if a complaint arises in the same incident for at least a period of six months; 
(3)  To prescribe forms, approved by the city attorney, for the disclosure required in this article and to make available to the public information disclosed as provided in this section; 
(4)  To receive and hear complaints of violations of the standards required by this article; 
(5)  To make such investigation and response to a complaint as it deems necessary to determine whether any person has violated any provisions of this article; 
(6)  To hold such hearings and make such inquiries as deemed necessary to investigate and rule upon complaints; and 
(7)  To report its findings to the city council for such action as the city council deems appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. II, § 14, 1-14-2008) 
Sec. 2-136. - Service of complaint; hearings and disposition of complaints. 
The decision of the board of ethics and recommended penalty shall be rendered to mayor and council within five days of completion of the hearing by the board of ethics. The mayor shall call for a special called meeting within five days of receipt of the decision of the board of ethics to consider accepting or rejecting the decision. If accepted in whole or in part, the city council shall render its decision as to penalty at its next regular meeting. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. II, § 15, 1-14-2008; Ord. No. 2010-CO-01-654, § 2, 2-8-2010) 
Sec. 2-137. - Public reprimand or censure; member rights. 
(a)  Any member of the city council who knowingly violates any provision of the code of ethics provided in this article shall be subject to public reprimand or censure by the city council. 
(b)  At any hearing held by the board of ethics, the member of the city council who is the subject of inquiry shall have the right to written notice of the allegations at least ten business days before a hearing, to be represented by counsel, to hear and examine the evidence and witnesses and to present evidence and witnesses in opposition or in extenuation. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. II, § 16, 1-14-2008) 
Sec. 2-138. - Appeals. 
(a)  Any member of the city council or the complainant adversely affected by any findings or decision of the board of ethics upon acceptance or rejection by the city council may obtain judicial review of such final city council action as provided in this section. 
(b)  An action for judicial review may be commenced by filing an application for a writ of certiorari in the Superior Court of Hall County within 30 days after the decision of the city council to accept or reject the decision of the board of ethics. The filing of such application shall act as supersedes. 
(Ord. No. 2010-CO-01-654, § 3, 2-8-2010) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2010-CO-01-654, § 3, 2-8-2010, deleted § 2-138 in its entirety and enacted new provisions to read as herein set out. Prior to amendment, § 2-138 pertained to similar subject matter. See Code Comparative Table for derivation. 
Sec. 2-139. - Conflict of interest. 
No employee of the city shall knowingly engage in any business or transaction or have a financial or other personal interest, direct or indirect, which is incompatible with the proper discharge of his official duties or which would tend to impair his independence of judgment or action in the performance of his official duties. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. III, § 1, 1-14-2008) 
Sec. 2-140. - Acceptance of gifts, gratuities, special privileges. 
(a)  Employees shall not accept any gifts, loans, rewards, favors or services that may reasonably tend to improperly influence them in the discharge of their official duties. This limitation is not intended to prohibit the acceptance of articles of negligible value which are distributed generally nor to prohibit employees from accepting loans from regular lending institutions. It is particularly important that employees guard against relationships which might be construed as or give the appearance of favoritism, coercion, unfair advantage or collusion. 
(b)  Employees shall not accept payment from outside sources for professional services (e.g., teaching, instructing, speaking engagements, consulting, honorariums) when such activities are done on city time or when such services pertain to the purchase or sale of city property. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. III, § 2, 1-14-2008) 
Sec. 2-141. - Proprietorship of creations. 
All plans, designs, reports, specifications, drawings, devices, inventions and other items produced or created by employees during working hours or through the use of city facilities or equipment or at the request of the city shall be and become the sole property of the city. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. III, § 3, 1-14-2008) 
Sec. 2-142. - Confidential information. 
Employees shall not disclose confidential information gained by reason of their official position nor shall they otherwise use such information for their personal gain or benefit. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. III, § 4, 1-14-2008) 
Sec. 2-143. - Specific conflicts of interest. 
(a)  If an employee of the city is an officer, director, agent or member of, or owns interest in any entity which is subject to the regulation of, or which has financial commitments with the city, he shall file a sworn statement to this effect with the city clerk. 
(b)  Employees shall not transact any business in their official capacity with any business entity of which he is an officer, director, agent, member or in which he owns a controlling interest excluding civic, charitable or religious organizations. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. III, § 5, 1-14-2008) 
Sec. 2-144. - Political activity. 
(a)  No person employed by the city shall either publicly or otherwise hold himself out as a candidate in any city election while holding employment with the city. 
(b)  City employees shall not take part in any political management of political campaigns in the election of mayor or any member of the city council during any period of time for which he is expected to perform work or receive compensation from the city. 
(c)  No employee, official or other person shall solicit, orally or by letter, or be in any other manner concerned in obtaining any assessments, contributions or services for any political party from any employee during his hours of duty, service or work with the city. 
(d)  Employees shall not represent the city by wearing any uniform or portion thereof that is issued by the city while he is participating in any campaign at any time. 
(e)  The city in no way seeks to influence employees in their choice of party affiliations or candidates, recognizing that this is a matter for each person to decide. Therefore, nothing contained herein shall be construed to restrict the right of the employee to hold membership in and support a political party, to vote as he chooses, to express opinions on political subjects or candidates, to maintain political neutrality, to attend political parties after work hours or to campaign actively during off duty hours in all areas of political activity. 
(f)  Employees shall not utilize any city equipment or vehicles in support of any political campaign. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. III, § 6, 1-14-2008) 
Sec. 2-145. - Outside employment; limitations and approval requirement. 
(a)  City employment shall be considered to be the primary employment of all full-time employees. No employee may engage in outside employment which will interfere with the interests of city service. Standards by which such employment is not acceptable include, but is not limited to: 
(1)  Illegal activity; 
(2)  Employment that by virtue of association will reflect upon the reputation of the city; 
(3)  High hazard or fatiguing work which might detract from or reduce city performance. 
(b)  Prior to beginning any regularly scheduled outside employment, employees will obtain specific written approval from their department head or his designee on request forms which indicate the name of the outside employer, the nature of the work, hours of work, address and telephone number where the employee can be reached. Such information will become a part of the employee's official personnel record. Employees are required to obtain approval from their department head or his designee for any change in a previously approved outside employment request. 
(c)  Any employee accepting or engaging in outside employment under the terms of this rule shall make arrangements with the outside employer to be available to respond immediately to any emergency call of duty whenever the department head or his designee shall determine that the employee's services are necessary. 
(d)  Employees sustaining injuries while engaged in outside employment are normally ineligible to receive benefits under the city's worker's compensation program. If an employee sustains an injury while engaged in outside employment but is performing duties within the scope of his city responsibilities (i.e., a police arrest), he may be eligible for partial city worker's compensation benefits. 
(e)  Failure to comply with the provisions of this section will result in disciplinary action. 
(Ord. No. 554, art. III, § 7, 1-14-2008) 
Secs. 2-146—2-173. - Reserved.

DIVISION 2. - BUDGETS 

Sec. 2-200. - Fiscal year. 
The city shall operate on a fiscal (calendar) year which shall begin on January 1 and end on December 31. 
(Ord. No. 563, art. II, 8-11-2008) 
Sec. 2-201. - Budget proposal deadline. 
The city manager shall prepare the proposed budget goals and budget schedule for the city council's consideration no later than August 1 for the ensuing fiscal year. 
(Ord. No. 563, art. III, § 1, 8-11-2008) 
Sec. 2-202. - Budget preparation schedule. 
The budget preparation schedule will include milestones for the following: 
(1)  Current year revenue and operating, salary and capital expenditure projections. 
(2)  Budget kickoff meeting with department managers. 
(3)  Public hearings for setting the tax millage rate. 
(4)  Work sessions for the city manager to present proposed operating budget, capital improvement program and capital budget to the mayor and city council for review. Scope, content and form shall be in accordance with generally accepted local government accounting practices. 
(5)  Adoption of tax millage rate. 
(6)  City manager presentation of the final fiscal budget at a public hearing. 
(7)  Adoption of fiscal budget by the mayor and city council. 
(8)  Distribution of adopted budget to department managers and mayor and city council. 
(Ord. No. 563, art. III, § 2, 8-11-2008)

The city manager will operate the city in accordance with the adopted budget. Any proposed amendments to the budget will be submitted to the mayor and city council for consideration as needed. 
(Ord. No. 563, art. III, § 3, 8-11-2008)
