(1)  Name of the subdivision and street names. 
(2)  Name, address and phone number of owners of record. 
(3)  Name, address and phone number of subdivider. 
(4)  Date of plat drawing, graphic scale, north point, notation as to the reference of bearings to magnetic, true north, or grid north, and indication whether bearings shown are calculated from angles turned or taken from compass readings. 
(5)  Location of tract (land district and land lot), location sketch and acreage. 
(6)  Courses and distances to the nearest existing street intersections or bench marks or other recognized permanent monuments. 
(7)  Exact boundary lines of the tract, to be indicated by a heavy line, giving distances to the nearest one-hundredth-foot and bearings to the nearest second, determined by an accurate field survey. 
(8)  Street centerlines showing angles of deflection and standard curve data of intersection, radii, length of tangents and arcs, and degree of curvature with basis of curve data. 
(9)  Municipal, county and land lot lines accurately tied to the lines of the subdivision by distance and angles when such lines traverse or immediately adjoin the subdivision. 
(10)  Exact locations, right-of-way and pavement widths, and names of all streets and alleys within and immediately adjoining the subdivision. 
(11)  Lot lines with dimensions to the nearest one-hundredth-foot, necessary internal angles, arcs, and chords and tangent or radii of rounded corners. 
(12)  The acreage or square footage of the area of each lot, and the total number of lots in the subdivision. 
(13)  Front yard/building setback lines with dimensions. 
(14)  Lots numbered in numerical order, regardless of the number of phases or sections. 
(15)  Accurate location, material and description of monuments and markers. 
(16)  Location, dimensions and purposes of easements and areas to be reserved or dedicated for public use. 
(17)  A statement, either directly on the plat or in an identified attached document of private covenants, if any. 
(18)  Areas within the intermediate regional flood (IRF) (i.e., 100-year flood) shall be determined by a professional engineer and shall be shown on the plat, including location and elevation of the intermediate regional flood. 
(19)  Names of record of owners of adjoining unplatted land, and the name of subdivisions and blocks and lot numbers for adjoining platted land. 
(20)  The following certifications (forms for which are maintained and available from the city clerk): 
a.  Final surveyor's certificate. 
b.  Owner's certificate of ownership and dedication to public use streets, alleys, easements and other public areas, signed by the owner. 
c.  Certification by the county health department that the plat and proposed water and sewage facilities are acceptable. 
d.  The zoning administrator's signature indicating approval of the final plat. 
e.  Certificate of recording. 
(21)  A statement that final plat approval does not constitute acceptance of public streets, easements and areas. 
(Ord. No. 221, § 311, 4-11-1994) 
Sec. 44-52. - Action on the final plat. 
Upon receipt of the completed final plat application materials, the zoning administrator may transmit for review and comment a copy of the plat to applicable review agencies. The city planning commission shall have 45 days to recommend approval or disapproval of the plat. Upon recommendation by the planning commission, the plat shall be submitted for action by the city council at its next regularly scheduled meeting or special called meeting. If approved by the city council, the signature of the zoning administrator shall be placed on the reproducible film copy or original of the plat and his signature shall constitute the city's final approval. 
(Ord. No. 221, § 312, 4-11-1994) 
Sec. 44-53. - Combinations and replats. 
Where separate lots of land are proposed to be combined or replatted, but where the resulting number of lots is not increased, they shall be submitted to the zoning administrator as a final plat for review, approval and recording. Said plat shall contain all information and certificates as specified in section 44-51; provided, however, the zoning administrator may waive certain of these specific information requirements if determined not to be essential. Such combinations and/or replats shall indicate in writing on the plat in a conspicuous place, numbered and dated consecutively, of all revisions to the plat. Said plat shall require a fee as a final plat. 
(Ord. No. 221, § 313, 4-11-1994) 
Sec. 44-54. - Recording of final plats. 
Upon approval and without undue delay, the zoning administrator shall have the final plat recorded in the records of the clerk of the superior court of the county, and a time-stable, reproducible film copy or original filed in the office of the zoning administrator. Said copy of the original shall not require an engineer or surveyor's stamp to protect the liability of the professionals involved. Recording fees shall be included in the fee charged for final plats and therefore paid by the city. The clerk of the superior court shall indicate on the filed copy, as well as the time-stable, reproducible film copy or original, the book and page number in the county records where the final plat is recorded. Recordation of a final plat constitutes approval to begin the sale or transfer of subdivision lots. 
(Ord. No. 221, § 314, 4-11-1994) 
Sec. 44-55. - Assignment of street addresses. 
Upon recording of a final plat, the zoning administrator shall assign each lot a street address and shall note each address in permanent ink on the time-stable, reproducible film copy or original. 
(Ord. No. 221, § 315, 4-11-1994) 
Sec. 44-56. - Distribution of recorded final plat. 
(a)  The final plat is a source of essential information to tax officials, public safety officials, and utility officials, among others. The zoning administrator shall be responsible for ensuring that each agency listed in this section receives a copy of the final recorded plat with assigned addresses: 
(1)  The county tax commissioner. 
(2)  The county tax assessor. 
(3)  The county health department. 
(4)  The city police department. 
(5)  The city building inspector. 
(6)  The city engineer. 
(7)  The United States Postal Service (local postmaster). 
(b)  At the discretion of the zoning administrator, additional agencies or persons may be added to the list in subsection (a) of this section. 
(Ord. No. 221, § 316, 4-11-1994) 
Sec. 44-57. - Acceptance of public streets and improvements. 
At any date after one year has passed since the date of final plat approval, the subdivider or land developer may petition the city council, in writing, to accept public streets and other improvements, in whole or in part, within the subdivision. Said improvements shall not be accepted for maintenance until approved by the city council. Any instrument of financial guarantee shall be returned to the subdivider upon acceptance of public streets and improvements by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 221, § 317, 4-11-1994) 
Secs. 44-58—44-87. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - GENERAL DESIGN AND OTHER REQUIREMENTS 

Sec. 44-88. - Suitability of land. 
Land subject to the flooding, improper drainage or erosion, or that is, for topographical or other reasons, unsuitable for residential use, shall not be platted for residential use nor any other use that will continue or increase the danger to health, safety, or proper construction, unless hazards can be and are corrected. 
(Ord. No. 221, § 401, 4-11-1994) 
Sec. 44-89. - Name of subdivision. 
The name of the subdivision must have the approval of the zoning administrator. The name shall not duplicate nor closely approximate the name of an existing subdivision in the city or county. 
(Ord. No. 221, § 402, 4-11-1994) 
Sec. 44-90. - Access. 
Access to every subdivision shall be provided over a public street. 
(Ord. No. 221, § 403, 4-11-1994) 
Sec. 44-91. - Conformance to adopted major thoroughfare and other plans. 
(a)  All streets and other features of the major thoroughfare plan of the city, if adopted by the city council, shall be platted by the subdivider in the location and to the dimension indicated on the major thoroughfare plan. In subdivisions related to or affecting any state or federally numbered highway, the approval of the state department of transportation may be required by the zoning administrator. 
(b)  When features of other plans adopted by the city (such as schools or other public building sites, parks or other land for public uses) are located in whole or in part in a land subdivision, such features shall either be dedicated or reserved by the subdivider for acquisition within a six-month period from the date of preliminary plat submittal by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 221, § 404, 4-11-1994) 
Sec. 44-92. - Continuation of existing streets. 
Existing streets shall be continued at the same or greater width, but in no case less than the required width. 
(Ord. No. 221, § 405, 4-11-1994) 
Sec. 44-93. - Street names. 
Street names shall be approved by the zoning administrator. Streets that are in alignment with existing named streets shall be given the name of the existing street. Names of new streets shall not duplicate or closely approximate those of existing streets in the city or county. 
(Ord. No. 221, § 406, 4-11-1994) 
Sec. 44-94. - Street jogs. 
Street jogs with centerline offsets of less than 200 feet shall not be permitted. 
(Ord. No. 2010-CO-11-666, § 1, 12-13-2010) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2010-CO-11-666, § 1, adopted Dec. 13, 2010, deleted § 44-94, in its entirety and enacted new provisions to read as herein set out. Prior to this amendment, § 44-94 pertained to similar subject matter. See Code Comparative Table for derivation. 
Sec. 44-95. - Development along arterial street or limited access highway. 
Where a subdivision abuts or contains an arterial street or a limited access highway, the zoning administrator may require a street approximately parallel to and on one or both sides of such right-of-way and shall require a ten-foot-wide easement, no-access or land reservation to ensure no access. 
(Ord. No. 221, § 408, 4-11-1994) 
Sec. 44-96. - Alleys. 
Alleys may be provided at the rear of lots used for multifamily, commercial or industrial developments, but shall not be provided in one- or two-family residential developments unless the subdivider provides evidence satisfactory to the zoning administrator of the need for alleys. 
(Ord. No. 221, § 409, 4-11-1994) 
Sec. 44-97. - Reserve strips. 
Reserve strips controlling access to streets, alleys, or public grounds shall not be permitted unless their control is placed in the hands of the city council, under conditions approved by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 221, § 410, 4-11-1994) 
Sec. 44-98. - Easements. 
(a)  Easements having a minimum width of 15 feet shall be provided, where required for utility lines, storm drains, and underground mains and cables. 
(b)  When a subdivision is traversed by a watercourse, drainageway, channel or stream, there shall be provided a stormwater or drainage easement of adequate width (minimum 20 feet) approved by the zoning administrator. Parallel streets may be required by the zoning administrator in connection therewith. 
(Ord. No. 221, § 411, 4-11-1994) 
Sec. 44-99. - Culs-de-sac. 
(a)  Except where topographic or other conditions make a greater length unavoidable, culs-de-sac or dead-end streets shall not be greater in length than 1,000 feet unless approved by the zoning administrator and shall be provided at the closed end with a turn-around. 
(b)  Where a subdivision contains a dead-end street other than a cul-de-sac, the zoning administrator may require the subdivider to provide a temporary vehicular turn-around within the right-of-way, when the zoning administrator considers such to be necessary for effective traffic circulation. 
(Ord. No. 221, § 412, 4-11-1994) 
Sec. 44-100. - Street right-of-way widths. 
The right-of-way width shall be the distance across a street from property line to property line. Minimum street right-of-way widths shall extend a minimum of 13 feet from the back-of-curb, and the total width shall be evenly divisible by ten feet. 
(Ord. No. 2010-CO-11-666, § 2, 12-13-2010) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2010-CO-11-666, § 2, adopted Dec. 13, 2010, deleted § 44-100, in its entirety and enacted new provisions to read as herein set out. Prior to this amendment, § 44-100 pertained to similar subject matter. See Code Comparative Table for derivation. 
Sec. 44-101. - Street pavement widths. 
Minimum street pavement widths shall be as follows measured from back of curb to back of curb: 
(1)  Arterial streets, as shown in the major thoroughfare plan. 
(2)  Collector streets, as shown in the major thoroughfare plan. 
(3)  Minor streets and dead-end streets, 24 feet. 
(4)  Minor streets, commercial and industrial subdivisions, 28 feet. 
(5)  Alleys, 14 feet. 
(6)  Culs-de-sac, commercial and industrial subdivisions, 50 feet radius. 
(7)  Culs-de-sac, local residential streets, 40 feet radius. 
(Ord. No. 2010-CO-11-666, § 3, 12-13-2010) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2010-CO-11-666, § 3, adopted Dec. 13, 2010, deleted § 44-101, in its entirety and enacted new provisions to read as herein set out. Prior to this amendment, § 44-101 pertained to similar subject matter. See Code Comparative Table for derivation. 
Sec. 44-102. - Vertical alignment. 
Maximum and minimum street grades shall be as follows: 
(1)  Arterial streets, not in excess of seven percent. 
(2)  Collector streets, not in excess of ten percent. 
(3)  Minor streets and dead-end streets and alleys, not in excess of 15 percent. (Ten percent for nonresidential streets). 
(4)  No street grade shall be less than one percent. 
Minimum design speeds shall be as follows: 
(1)  Arterial streets- 45 miles per hour. 
(2)  Collector streets- 45 miles per hour. 
(3)  Minor streets and dead-end streets and alleys- 25 miles per hour. 
(Ord. No. 2010-CO-11-666, § 4, 12-13-2010) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2010-CO-11-666, § 4, adopted Dec. 13, 2010, deleted § 44-102, in its entirety and enacted new provisions to read as herein set out. Prior to this amendment, § 44-102 pertained to similar subject matter. See Code Comparative Table for derivation. 
Sec. 44-103. - Horizontal curvature. 
The minimum radii of centerline curvature shall be as follows: 
(1)  Arterial streets, 800 feet. 
(2)  Collector streets, 200 feet. 
(3)  Minor streets and dead-end streets and alleys, 100 feet. 
(Ord. No. 2010-CO-11-666, § 5, 12-13-2010) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2010-CO-11-666, § 5, adopted Dec. 13, 2010, deleted § 44-103, in its entirety and enacted new provisions to read as herein set out. Prior to this amendment, § 44-103 pertained to similar subject matter. See Code Comparative Table for derivation. 
Sec. 44-104. - Tangents. 
Between reverse curves, there shall be a tangent having a length not less than the following: 
(1)  Arterial streets, 200 feet. 
(2)  Collector streets, 100 feet. 
(3)  Minor streets and dead-end streets and alleys, 50 feet. 
(Ord. No. 221, § 417, 4-11-1994) 
Sec. 44-105. - Sight distance requirements. 
Alignment shall be such that the following requirements are met: 
(1)  Major streets shall have a sight distance of at least 500 feet at four feet above ground level. 
(2)  Collector streets shall have a sight distance of at least 300 feet at four feet above ground level. 
(3)  Minor streets shall have a sight distance of at least 200 feet at four feet above ground level. 
(Ord. No. 2010-CO-11-666, § 6, 12-13-2010) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2010-CO-11-666, § 6, adopted Dec. 13, 2010, deleted § 44-105, in its entirety and enacted new provisions to read as herein set out. Prior to this amendment, § 44-105 pertained to vertical alignment. See Code Comparative Table for derivation. 
Sec. 44-106. - Street intersections. 
Street intersections shall be as nearly at right angles as possible. No street intersections shall be at an angle of less than 65 degrees, unless required by unusual circumstances. Maximum intersection grade shall not exceed three percent. 
(Ord. No. 2010-CO-11-666, § 7, 12-13-2010) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2010-CO-11-666, § 7, adopted Dec. 13, 2010, deleted § 44-106, in its entirety and enacted new provisions to read as herein set out. Prior to this amendment, § 44-106 pertained to similar subject matter. See Code Comparative Table for derivation. 
Sec. 44-107. - Curbline radius. 
The curbline radius at street intersections shall be at least 30 feet. Where the angle of street intersection is less than 90 degrees, a longer radius may be required. For commercial and industrial subdivision streets, a minimum 40-foot curbline radius shall be provided. 
(Ord. No. 221, § 420, 4-11-1994) 
Sec. 44-108. - Block lengths and widths. 
Block lengths and widths shall be as follows: 
(1)  In general, residential blocks shall be not greater than 1,800 feet nor less than 600 feet in length. 
(2)  Blocks shall be wide enough to provide two tiers of lots of minimum depth, except where abutting upon major arterial streets, or limited-access highways, or where other situations make this requirement impracticable. 
(Ord. No. 221, § 421, 4-11-1994) 
Sec. 44-109. - Lot sizes. 
(a)  Lots shall meet the lot width and lot area requirements of chapter 54, zoning. 
(b)  Residential lots shall have a depth of not less than 100 feet and not greater than three times the width of the lot at the building line, unless unusual circumstances make these limitations not practicable. 
(c)  Where individual septic tanks are used, the county health department shall approve minimum lot sizes to conform to health standards of the state department of public health. 
(Ord. No. 221, § 422, 4-11-1994) 
Sec. 44-110. - Lot lines. 
All lot lines shall be perpendicular or radial to street lines, unless not practicable because of topographic or other features. 
(Ord. No. 221, § 423, 4-11-1994) 
Sec. 44-111. - Building lines. 
A building line meeting the front yard setback requirements of chapter 54, zoning, as a minimum, shall be established on all lots. 
(Ord. No. 221, § 424, 4-11-1994) 
Sec. 44-112. - Lot frontage. 
Each lot shall abut a minimum of 30 feet on a public street. 
(Ord. No. 221, § 425, 4-11-1994) 
Sec. 44-113. - Double and reverse frontage lots. 
Double frontage and reverse frontage lots should be avoided except where essential to provide separation of residential development from traffic arteries or overcome specific disadvantages of topography or orientation. 
(Ord. No. 221, § 426, 4-11-1994) 
Sec. 44-114. - Panhandle or flag lots. 
Panhandle lots or flag lots are discouraged, but if designed with the required width and area they may be allowed where terrain makes standard design or frontage impossible or impractical. Where such lots are allowed, the street frontage of each panhandle access shall not be less than 30 feet wide, and the panhandle access shall be not more than 200 feet long. Not more than two such panhandle lots shall abut each other. 
(Ord. No. 221, § 427, 4-11-1994) 
Secs. 44-115—44-141. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - REQUIRED IMPROVEMENTS AND CONSTRUCTION SPECIFICATIONS 

Sec. 44-142. - Street right-of-way clearance. 
All trees, brush, stumps, rocks, or other debris shall be cleared from the street right-of-way as required, except in cases where shade trees are required to be preserved by the zoning administrator. 
(Ord. No. 221, § 501, 4-11-1994) 
Sec. 44-143. - Grading of streets. 
All streets shall be graded to lines, grades and cross sections approved on the plans. 
(Ord. No. 221, § 502, 4-11-1994) 
Sec. 44-144. - Street paving and base. 
(a)  Base course construction; general specifications. 
(1)  Arterial and collector streets: The base course shall consist of graded aggregate of a minimum compacted thickness of eight inches placed on a stabilized sub-base in accordance with these specifications and in conformity with the lines, grade, and typical cross-section as shown on the drawings approved by the city. 
(2)  Minor and dead-end streets: The base course shall consist of graded aggregate of a minimum compacted thickness of six inches placed on a stabilized sub-base in accordance with these specifications and in conformity with the lines, grade, and typical cross-section as shown on the drawings approved by the city. 
(3)  Turn lanes and deceleration lanes: The base course shall consist of graded aggregate of a minimum compacted thickness of eight inches placed on a stabilized sub-base in accordance with these specifications and in conformity with the lines, grade, and typical cross-section as shown on the drawings approved by the city. 
(4)  Base course construction; materials: All materials shall be secured from Georgia Department of Transportation approved sources. 
(5)  Base course construction; preparation of sub-grade: All boulders, organic material, soft clay, spongy material and any other objectionable material shall be removed and replaced with approved material. The sub-grade shall be properly shaped, rolled and uniformly compacted to conform to the lines, grades and typical cross-sections as shown on the drawings approved by the city. 
(6)  Base course construction; placing and rolling aggregate: All base course material shall be deposited and spread by means of spreader boxes, or approved mechanical equipment, or from moving vehicles equipped to distribute the material in a uniform layer. Each layer shall be not more than two inches in thickness after compaction and shall be constructed as follows: 
a.  Immediately following the spreading of the coarse aggregate, all material placed shall be compacted to the full width by rolling with a smooth wheel power roller weighing seven to ten tons, or an equivalent sheep-foot packer. Rolling shall progress gradually from the sides to the center, parallel with the centerline of the street and lapping uniformly each preceding track by one-half the width of such track, and shall continue until all the surface has been rolled and has been thoroughly keyed, and the interstices of the stone reduced to a minimum, and until it ceases to creep or wave ahead of the roller. 
b.  Any irregularities or depressions that develop under such rolling shall be corrected by loosening the material at these places and adding or removing material until the surface is smooth and uniform. 
c.  After the coarse aggregate has been thoroughly keyed and set by the rolling described above, screenings in an amount that will completely fill the interstices shall be applied gradually over the surface and rolling shall be continued while the screenings are being spread, so that the jarring effect of the roller will cause the screenings to settle into the voids of the coarse aggregate. 
d.  The screenings shall not be dumped in piles on the coarse aggregate but shall be spread in thin layers, either by spreading motion with hand shovels, by mechanical spreading or directly from trucks. 
e.  In no case shall the screening be applied so fast or thickly as to cake or bridge on the surface in such manner as to prevent the filling of all voids or prevent the direct bearing of the roller on the coarse aggregate. 
f.  Hand brooms shall be used to sweep the screenings into unfilled voids and to distribute the stone where needed. The spreading, sweeping and rolling shall continue until no more screenings can be forced into the void. 
g.  Shaping and rolling shall be performed alternately as required to maintain a uniform compacted base until a surface or treatment has been applied to the base. 
h.  Along curbs, headers and walls and at all places not accessible to the roller, the base course material shall be tamped thoroughly with mechanical tampers or approved hand tampers. 
i.  Base course construction; seasonal limits on construction. No base material shall be deposited or shaped when the sub-grade is frozen or thawing or during unfavorable weather conditions. 
(b)  Bituminous plant mix paving. 
(1)  Arterial and collector streets: Bituminous plant mix paving shall consist of a minimum of two-inch asphaltic concrete "E" mix placed on top of a minimum of four-inch asphaltic concrete binder "B" mix. 
(2)  Minor and dead end streets: Bituminous plant mix paving shall consist of a minimum of one-inch asphaltic concrete "F" mix placed on top of a minimum of two-inch asphaltic concrete binder "B" mix. 
(3)  Turn lanes and deceleration lanes: Bituminous plant mix paving shall consist of a minimum of one-inch asphaltic concrete "F" mix placed on top of a minimum of four-inch asphaltic concrete binder "B" mix. 
(4)  Bituminous plant mix materials: All materials shall be secured from Georgia Department of Transportation approved sources and conform to the latest equivalent GDOT standards. 
(Ord. No. 2010-CO-11-666, § 8, 12-13-2010) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2010-CO-11-666, § 8, adopted Dec. 13, 2010, deleted § 44-144, in its entirety and enacted new provisions to read as herein set out. Prior to this amendment, § 44-144 pertained to similar subject matter. See Code Comparative Table for derivation. 
Sec. 44-145. - Curb and gutter. 
(a)  Curb and gutter shall be installed along both sides of all paving. All curb and gutter shall conform to city specifications. Curb and gutter construction shall be of 3000 psi concrete 24 inches wide as further detailed in the City of Oakwood design standards. 
(b)  Curb and gutter requirements; construction standards: The curb and gutter shall be so constructed as to present a smooth, even line both vertically and horizontally, in accordance with the Georgia D.O.T. standards. There shall be one-half inch expansion joints placed every 50 feet and pre-shaped contraction joints every ten feet along the curb and gutter. 
(Ord. No. 2010-CO-11-666, § 9, 12-13-2010) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2010-CO-11-666, § 9, adopted Dec. 13, 2010, deleted § 44-145, in its entirety and enacted new provisions to read as herein set out. Prior to this amendment, § 44-145 pertained to similar subject matter. See Code Comparative Table for derivation. 
Sec. 44-146. - Street signs. 
(a)  Street name signs shall be furnished and installed at all street intersections on the rights-of-way by the developer. Signs shall be retro-reflective, high intensity grade on nine-foot blades with blue background with six-inch white legends, upper and lower case, mounted on ten-foot galvanized U-channel posts. Exact locations and proofs of street name signs shall be approved by the zoning administrator prior to production and installation. 
(b)  Traffic signs shall comply with the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices (MUTCD) and be installed on ten-foot galvanized U-channel posts by the developer. 
(Ord. No. 2010-CO-11-666, § 10, 12-13-2010) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2010-CO-11-666, § 10, adopted Dec. 13, 2010, deleted § 44-146, in its entirety and enacted new provisions to read as herein set out. Prior to this amendment, § 44-146 pertained to similar subject matter. See Code Comparative Table for derivation. 
Sec. 44-147. - Street right-of-way improvements. 
All street rights-of-way outside of the paved portions shall be graded to conform with approved cross section and shall be grassed as directed by the zoning administrator. 
(Ord. No. 221, § 506, 4-11-1994) 
Sec. 44-148. - Shade trees. 
Shade trees and other shrubbery that may be retained or planted shall be placed or retained so as not to obstruct sight distances at street intersections. 
(Ord. No. 221, § 507, 4-11-1994) 
Sec. 44-149. - Sidewalks. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person and/or his agent to hereafter install, construct, or lay, or cause to be installed, constructed or laid, any sidewalk or sidewalks within the street lines of the city without first obtaining a permit authorizing the same from the city. 
(b)  Any sidewalk hereafter constructed within the street lines of the city by any person shall be constructed in strict compliance with specifications and plans and upon grades and lines to be approved by the city engineer. 
(Ord. No. 221, § 508, 4-11-1994; Amd. No. 221, § 1, 10-10-2005) 
Sec. 44-150. - Sidewalks required. 
(a)  Sidewalks shall be provided within all single-family subdivisions. 
(b)  Sidewalks shall be provided along the street from which a multifamily development has access and along all other adjoining streets. 
(c)  Sidewalks shall be provided along all streets adjoining a nonresidential development. 
(Amd. No. 221, § 1, 10-10-2005) 
Sec. 44-151. - Location requirements. 
(a)  Sidewalks shall be required adjacent to both sides of internal subdivision streets in both residential and nonresidential developments. 
(b)  Sidewalks shall be required adjacent to the perimeter of "eyebrow" turnarounds as well as cul-de-sac turnarounds. 
(Amd. No. 221, § 1, 10-10-2005) 
Sec. 44-152. - Design standards. 
Sidewalks shall be constructed in accordance with the following design standards unless a modification is granted by the city manager or his designee: 
(1)  Sidewalks shall be located two feet from the back of existing curb. Where no curbing exists or proposed roads improvements are anticipated, sidewalks shall be placed in a location acceptable to the state department of transportation. 
(2)  All sidewalks shall match and provide a smooth at-grade transition to any existing sidewalks with no steps. 
(3)  Sidewalks shall be constructed of concrete and shall be a minimum of five feet in width and four inches thick. Concrete shall be class B (as defined by the state department of transportation) and have a strength of 3,000 psi at 28 days. 
(4)  Sidewalks shall be constructed on a four-inch foundation of compacted crushed gravel or crushed stone. 
(5)  Curb ramps shall be provided at all curb termini and shall be a minimum of four feet in width exclusive of flared sides. 
(6)  Expansion joints shall be provided at all property lines (extended) and driveway crossings. Control joints shall be provided every ten feet. 
(7)  Sidewalks shall slope one-quarter-inch per foot towards the street. 
(8)  Disturbed areas resulting from sidewalk construction shall be backfilled, stabilized, and grassed. 
(9)  All sidewalks shall be constructed to conform to requirements of the Americans With Disabilities Act (ADA). 
(Amd. No. 221, § 1, 10-10-2005) 
Sec. 44-153. - Installation deadlines. 
Sidewalks shall be installed prior to the issuance of a certificate of occupancy or final plat approval in accordance with this chapter unless a performance bond is posted. The cost of sidewalk installation may be set aside in escrow where proposed road improvements may impact the location of the sidewalk as follows: 
(1)  Sidewalks required on residential building lots within a subdivision shall be installed prior to issuance of a certificate of occupancy for each individual dwelling. 
(2)  Within a residential subdivision, sidewalks required along common areas or designated recreation areas shall be installed prior to final plat approval. 
(3)  Sidewalks required for all other development shall be installed prior to issuance of a certificate of occupancy, as appropriate. 
(Amd. No. 221, § 1, 10-10-2005) 
Sec. 44-154. - Storm drainage system. (See also the requirements of chapters 20 and 40 of this Code.) 
Storm drains, along with catchbasins and manholes, shall be installed in compliance with the plans and specifications, and as follows: 
(1)  Every subdivision shall be served by storm drainage facilities, including drains, sewers, catchbasins, culverts and other facilities as required by standards and specifications of the city. 
(2)  All drainage facilities shall be so designed to serve the entire drainage area in which these facilities are located. All street drains serving lots in the subdivision shall be installed by the subdivider. A formula may be developed by the city to provide for a sharing of the cost of other drainage facilities needed to serve the subdivision when certain of the required drainage facilities are necessary to serve other subdivisions in the same drainage basin. 
(3)  All surface water drainage shall be transported to existing storm sewers or to drainage facilities approved by the city. 
(4)  Whenever drainage ditches are used, such ditches shall retain natural design characteristics and be so designed that they do not present a hazard to life and safety or create erosion problems. 
(5)  All drainage features shall be in accordance with standards and specifications of the city, and no extension shall be made from the street drainage through the abutting property without approval of the city. 
(6)  When the construction of a proposed public road makes it necessary to cross a storm drain, the developer shall provide and install the required size and length of an acceptable grade of pipe. The length of the pipe required shall be measured from a point 60 feet to the rear of the established building line on the upstream side of the road to a point 60 feet beyond the building line on the downstream side of the road and in no case shall the extension be less than 30 feet from the rear of any proposed dwelling; provided, however, the drain runs through building lots proposed to be platted. 
a.  In cases where the developer or owner chooses not to develop the land through which the drain runs, then the trench may be left open, however, in such cases the plat must be so marked and an easement shown thereon, indicating that no building or driveway shall be built over or within 40 feet of the open drain. 
b.  Where the developer chooses to leave the drain open and same is crossed by a driveway, the size of pipe shall be determined by the city and no building permit will be approved unless the installation meets the requirements of the city. 
c.  Notwithstanding the controls in this subsection (6), the zoning administrator may refuse to issue a building permit on any lot or lots where the land is subject to floods or where, in the opinion of the city engineer, the topographic features of the property are such that a building could not be properly maintained on the lot. 
(Ord. No. 221, § 509, 4-11-1994; Ord. No. 2010-CO-11-666, § 11, 12-13-2010) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2010-CO-11-666, § 11, adopted Dec. 13, 2010, renamed § 44-154 from "Storm drainage system. (See also the requirements of chapter 20 requirements)" to "Storm drainage system. (See also the requirements of chapters 20 and 40 of this Code)". 
Sec. 44-155. - Water system and fire hydrants. 
All water mains shall be installed along with a service connection for each lot and be in operating condition prior to final plat approval and paving installation. This system shall be connected to the city water system or a source accepted by the county health department. All pipe, valves, hydrants, and other components shall conform to city and county health department specifications and regulations. Fire hydrants shall be located and set in accordance with city specifications and as set forth in chapter 52. 
(Ord. No. 221, § 510, 4-11-1994) 
Sec. 44-156. - Sanitary sewage system. 
A subdivision or land development may be required to connect to a public sanitary sewer system, as required by chapter 52. 
(Ord. No. 221, § 511, 4-11-1994) 
Sec. 44-157. - Wastewater capacity allocation determination guidelines. 
As a supplement to the criteria set forth in this Code, the following guidelines are hereby established in an effort to properly balance residential, commercial and industrial development and to fairly and equitably allocate the city's limited wastewater capacity: 
(1)  The city will maintain a wastewater capacity allocation summary list which includes the project name, developer, number of units/lots at build-out, wastewater capacity requested and a record of the allocation and/or number of lots/units approved. As building permits are issued, wastewater allocations and available capacity will be adjusted accordingly. 
(2)  In order to balance residential, commercial and industrial development, the city will categorize and consider wastewater capacity requests in terms of proposed land use (e.g., industrial, commercial, office/professional, single-family residential and multifamily residential). 
(3)  Residential development will be granted allocation approval in a phased manner. In general, no more than 33 percent of the total dwellings, or a maximum of 50 units/lots, will be approved at any one time. 
(4)  The city manager is authorized to approve allocation requests demanding less than 1,500 gallons per day. 
(5)  Payments for wastewater capacity shall be made in accordance with the fees established by the city. Fifty percent of the wastewater capacity fee shall be paid within 60 days of approval of an allocation. The remaining 50 percent shall be paid as building permits are issued. Wastewater allocations not used within 24 months of payment may be redeemed by the city by refunding the wastewater capacity fees paid to date, less 20 percent, to the owner/developer. 
(6)  The owner/developer may not transfer wastewater capacity allocations from one development to another. 
(Amd. No. 120, 12-13-2004) 
Sec. 44-158. - Wastewater capacity waiting list and wastewater capacity allocation criteria. 
(a)  The city has established the following requirements for securing a position on the city's wastewater capacity waiting list and the following factors and procedures for the allocation available wastewater treatment capacity. 
(1)  Wastewater capacity waiting list. Any person who desires to become a new sewer customer, whether on behalf of such person or as a developer, shall make application for sewer service in accordance with procedures set forth by the city manager. This provision shall also apply to any existing customer who desires to increase its sewage rate of flow by more than ten percent or substantially increase or alter the pollutant characteristics of its sewage. 
(2)  Such persons shall specify the amount of sewer service capacity requested upon application in addition to such other information as may be requested by the city manager to further evaluate the criteria set forth in subsection (b) of this section. Applicants shall be allowed to secure a position on the sewer service waiting list if all of the following requirements are met: 
a.  The subject property is located within the city limits. 
b.  The subject property is property zoned for the anticipated use. 
c.  The applicant has an ownership interest in the subject property. 
d.  The subject property is now, or will be in the future, a public water customer. 
e.  The applicant agrees to pay the projected wastewater capacity fee upon allocation of capacity. 
Those applicants that are on the city's waiting list for sewer service as of the date of the adoption of the ordinance from which this article is derived shall remain on the list with their positions being determined based on the date their request for sewer service was submitted to the city; provided however, that any applicant on the city's waiting list as of the date of adoption of the ordinance from which this article is derived who cannot demonstrate that he meets the requirements in this subsection shall have 60 days from the date the ordinance from which this article is derived is passed within which to demonstrate compliance with the requirements or such person shall forfeit their place on the waiting list. 
(b)  Wastewater capacity allocation determinations. At such time as the mayor and city council can reasonably project available or soon-to-be available wastewater treatment capacity, the mayor and city council shall offer the available or soon-to-be available capacity to those qualified applicants on the current waiting list, in such amounts as determined to be appropriate. The mayor and city council's allocation of available or soon-to-be available wastewater treatment capacity among the pending requests for such capacity shall take into account the following factors: 
(1)  The length of time that the applicant has been on the waiting list. 
(2)  The applicant's willingness to enter into an agreement with the city for the purchase of wastewater treatment capacity. 
(3)  The date the applicant can commit to use, on a continual basis, the capacity requested. 
(4)  The extent to which the applicant is able to accept portions of the requested capacity in phases over a period of time. 
(5)  The waste loading of the projected wastewater, i.e., its projected characteristics, volume and impact on the wastewater treatment. 
(6)  The applicant's prior history of violations of applicable ordinances, laws, rules and regulations with regard to water quality and/or wastewater issues. 
(7)  The applicant's credit worthiness and financial ability to meet its obligations to the city. 
(8)  The current amount of unutilized allocation which the applicant has remaining. 
(c)  Wastewater capacity allocation process. After the mayor and city council have made their allocation determination, any applicant offered any amount of wastewater treatment capacity shall be required to: 
(1)  Enter into a binding agreement with the city for the provision of wastewater capacity. 
(2)  Pay the wastewater capacity fee as established and updated from time to time by the city. 
Any applicant unable to complete either of the above requirements within 60 days of the allocation, or within such later date established by the city, provided that good faith negotiations are proceeding in a diligent manner, shall forfeit the allocation offered to him and shall forfeit his position on the waiting list. 
(Amd. No. 120, § 1, 12-13-2004) 
Sec. 44-159. - Gas system. 
The gas system and any other underground system when it is to be installed in a subdivision or land development shall be installed along with service connections before any paving is laid. 
(Ord. No. 221, § 512, 4-11-1994) 
Sec. 44-160. - Monuments. 
(a)  Permanent monuments shall be accurately set and established at the following points: 
(1)  Where plat boundary lines intersect with land lot lines. 
(2)  Monuments shall consist of half-inch diameter metal pin or pipe, a minimum of 18 inches in length. 
(3)  The accurate location, material, and size of all existing monuments shall be shown, on the final plat, as well as the future location of monuments to be placed after street improvements have been completed. 
(b)  Monuments shall be placed at all corners of each lot and driven so as to be set two inches above the finished grade. 
(Ord. No. 221, § 513, 4-11-1994) 
Sec. 44-161. - Streetlights. 
(a)  New subdivisions (residential, commercial and industrial). Streetlights shall be provided by the developer of all subdivisions which propose the construction of a new street to be dedicated to the city or which propose lot access to an existing city street. 
(1)  Prior to the approval of a final plat, the developer shall submit a copy of the approved preliminary plat revised in accordance with this chapter showing the lighting design for the subdivision. The design, after approval by the city manager or his designee thereof, shall be forwarded to the appropriate power provider for approval and the developer shall pay the power provider the appropriate cost for materials and installation. Proof of payment to the power provider shall be required before approval of the final plat. 
(2)  All fixtures and poles shall meet the requirements of this chapter and all maintenance shall be the responsibility of the power provider. Fixtures shall be mounted a minimum of 16 feet above the ground and each fixture shall have appropriate arm length to illuminate the street. The city, in addition to other requirements, may require a light to be located at street intersections within the development. 
(3)  Upon acceptance of the streetlight installation by the city, the power provider shall submit monthly bills to the city clerk for payment. The city shall assign a special assessment to each property abutting a street with streetlights for payment of the monthly utility costs on a pro rata basis. 
(b)  Specifications. Unless otherwise specifically set forth herein, all of the material, methods of construction and workmanship for the work covered in reference to street construction shall conform to the latest specifications of the state department of transportation (Georgia DOT) and the following roadway lighting installation guidelines for the city: 
(1)  All roadway lighting facing city public streets (whether private security lighting or part of the street lighting program) must be approved by the city manager for the city. 
(2)  All lighting that is to be a part of the city lighting program shall be high-pressure sodium lighting. 
(c)  Lighting applications. 
(1)  Residential overhead lighting shall be cobra-head fixtures mounted on existing poles with fixtures to be supplied by the power provider. Bulbs shall be 100 to 150 watt high-pressure sodium spaced 300 to 325 feet apart. 
(2)  Residential underground lighting shall be mounted on decorative post top poles and fixtures unless otherwise specified by the city. Poles and fixtures shall be supplied by the power provider after payment by the developer/applicant. Bulbs shall be 100 to 150 watt high-pressure sodium fixtures mounted on 20-foot poles with a 16-foot mounting height, set back a minimum of six feet from the back of the curb and spaced 150 to 200 feet apart. 
(3)  Commercial and industrial overhead lighting shall be rated roadway fixtures mounted on existing poles with fixtures to be supplied by the power provider. Bulbs shall be either 250 watt high-pressure sodium spaced 275 feet apart or 400 watt high-pressure sodium spaced 325 feet apart. 
(4)  Commercial and industrial underground lighting shall be rated roadway fixtures mounted on steel poles with a minimum mounting height of 30 feet and set back a minimum of six feet from the back of the curb. Poles and fixtures shall be supplied by the power provider after payment by the developer/applicant. Bulbs shall be either 250 watt high-pressure sodium spaced 275 feet apart or 400 watt high-pressure sodium spaced 325 feet apart. 
(5)  Cutoff fixtures may be required. 
(6)  After installation of lights in accordance with the final plat approved by the city, lights shall not be removed unless deemed necessary by the city manager. Additional lights may be requested by individual homeowners upon written approval of all adjacent homeowners. 
(d)  Streetlight standards. 
(1)  The American Standard Practice for Roadway Lighting as sponsored by the Illuminating Engineering Society and approved by the American Standards Association on July 11, 1973, is hereby adopted as the standard (except as noted in subsection (c)(2) of this section) for installation and operation of street lighting. 
(2)  All fixtures installed for the purpose of street illumination shall comply with these standards. The minimum average horizontal footcandle illumination level by roadway classification shall be: 

 
(3)  The uniformity of illumination shall be such that the point of lowest illumination shall have at least one-third of the average horizontal footcandle required illumination level except that on local or residential street it may be not less than one-sixty of such average. 
(e)  Street lighting compliance to standards. 
(1)  Any party requesting permission to install or operate lighting fixtures within the public right-of-way shall furnish plans and specifications to the city manager or his designee for approval showing how the proposed lighting meets the standards and no lighting shall be installed or operated without such approval. Should the city manager or his designee disapprove the request to install or operate lighting fixtures within any public right-of-way, the city manager or designee shall communicate the disapproval in writing to the party requesting same. The written communication shall include the specific reasons for disapproval. Any disapproval of lighting or lighting system by the city manager or his designee may be appealed to the city council. If any party desires to appeal an adverse decision hereunder, a notice of appeal shall be filed with the city clerk within 30 days from the date following the written notice of disapproval and it shall be the responsibility of the city clerk to transmit forthwith to the city council all papers and allied documents constituting the record upon which the action appealed from was taken and to ensure that said appeal is promptly placed upon the agenda of the city council for its determination. The city council may reverse or affirm, wholly or partly, or may modify the order, requirement, decision or determination appealed from. 
(2)  Roadway or street lighting luminaries or fixtures installed within the public rights-of-way as security lights or for the purpose of lighting areas other than the public street shall be mounted on the side of the pole opposite from such street and shall be oriented in such a manner as to ensure that the lateral light distribution pattern is parallel to the street and the vertical light distribution at the initial light source is perpendicular to the street so as to protect the users of the street from objectionable glare. The approval of the city manager or his designee shall be obtained before installation of such lighting. 
(3)  Other lighting fixtures to be installed within or outside public rights-of-way for whatever purpose shall be installed and operated in such a manner to prevent glare from being a hazard to or interfering with the normal use of the public right-of-way. 
(f)  Installation of streetlights. The installation and operation of lighting fixtures located within the rights-of-way of any public street, road, highway, sidewalk or alley in the city or fixed to any pole, lamppost, standard or other supporting device which is located within such rights-of-way will follow the following procedures: 
(1)  Plans and specifications for the proposed installation showing compliance with the standard of the chapter shall be submitted to the city manger or his designee thereof for approval. No installations will be made without this approval. 
(2)  Fixtures illuminating areas adjoining the public streets, roads and the like such as parking area and driveways shall be mounted in such a manner as to ensure that the light pattern is kept off the public roadway. When street or roadway lighting luminaries are to be used for security lighting, they will be mounted on the side of the pole that is opposite from the public street and will be mounted to ensure that the lateral light distribution pattern is parallel to the street an the vertical light distribution at the initial light source is perpendicular to the street. 
(3)  If lighting fixtures of a type other than those in the classification of street or roadway luminaries are to be used or if the proposed lighting is to be for other than drives, parking areas or other similar area lighting, the plans and specifications submitted will be sufficiently detailed to clearly show that such a proposal is in compliance with these standards and will not cause a hazard to, or interfere with, the normal use of the public street, roads or highways. 
(Ord. No. 221, § 514, 4-11-1994; Amd. No. 221, § 1, 7-11-2005) 
Sec. 44-162. - Deceleration lanes and left-turn lanes. 
(a)  Deceleration lanes; where required. A deceleration lane shall be required at each entrance to a residential subdivision of 24 lots or more, commercial or industrial subdivision, multifamily development or nonresidential development at its point of access with a city collector or arterial street. Developments accessing a state route or county road must comply with access requirements and standards established by the respective jurisdiction. 
(b)  Median breaks. If the developer desires to construct or utilize an existing median break to serve the development, a left turn lane leading to the median break shall be required. 
(c)  Deceleration and turn lane constructions standards. 
(1)  If required, additional right-of-way to accommodate the deceleration lane or turn lane and a ten-foot shoulder shall be dedicated by the developer to the City of Oakwood. 
(2)  Curb and gutter along all deceleration lanes and tapers are required, and shall be constructed in accordance with section 44-145. 
(3)  Drainage improvements, as deemed necessary by the construction of the deceleration or turn lane, shall also be required. 
(4)  Other project access improvements may be required by the city engineer in addition to or in lieu of a required deceleration lane in order to ensure adequate site access, pedestrian access, convenience and safety to the motoring public. 
(5)  Utilities and drain pipes shall be relocated outside of the deceleration lane at the developer's expense. 
(Ord. No. 2010-CO-11-666, § 12, 12-13-2010) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2010-CO-11-666, § 12, adopted Dec. 13, 2010, deleted § 44-162, in its entirety and enacted new provisions to read as herein set out. Prior to this amendment, § 44-162 pertained to deceleration lanes. See Code Comparative Table for derivation. 
Sec. 44-163. - Driveway construction 
(a)  Permit required. An application for permit to construct or alter a driveway or curb cut occurring on or abutting city road right-of-way shall be made to the zoning administrator under the following circumstances: 
(1)  When such driveways or curb cuts are incidental to the development of a new structure or the development of previously undeveloped property, the driveway permit shall constitute a part of the building permit. 
(2)  When such driveway or curb cut construction constitutes a separate action apart from any other construction on the same site, a driveway permit shall be secured from the zoning administrator. 
(3)  When property abutting a city road right-of-way changes from one use to another and driveways and/or curb cuts have previously been extended across or to a city road right-of-way, or when the type of use or the volume of use of an existing and/or previously approved driveway is substantially changed, application for review shall be submitted and a driveway permit secured from the zoning administrator. Occupancy permit may be withheld until such driveway improvements have been approved. 
(4)  The island area on the right-of-way between successive driveways or adjoining a driveway and between the highway shoulder and right-of-way line shall remain unimproved for vehicular travel or parking. Such areas shall be considered as restricted and may be filled in or graded down only as hereinafter provided in subsection (a)(8) of this section. 
(5)  The surface of the driveway connecting with rural type highway sections shall slope down and away from the highway shoulder a sufficient amount and distance to preclude ordinary surface water drainage from the driveway area flowing onto the highway roadbed. 
(6)  The driveway shall not obstruct or impair drainage in side ditches or roadside areas. Driveway culverts, where necessary, shall be adequate for surface water drainage along the roadway and in no case less than equivalent of 15-inch diameter pipe. The distance between culverts under successive driveways shall be not less than ten feet except as such restricted area is permitted to be filled in under the provisions of subsection (a)(8) of this section. 
(7)  When curb and gutter are removed for constructing a driveway, the new connections shall be of equivalent acceptable material and curb returns provided or restored in a neat, workmanlike manner. The driveway surface shall connect with the highway pavement and the sidewalk, if any, in a neat workmanlike manner. The driveway construction shall include replacement by reason of vehicular travel across the sidewalk. 
(8)  The restricted area between successive driveways may be filled in or graded down only when the following requirements are fully complied with: 
a.  The filling or grading down shall be to grades approved by the zoning administrator; and except where drainage is by means of curb and gutter, water drainage of the area shall be directed away from the highway roadbed in a suitable manner. 
b.  Culvert extension under the restricted area shall be of like size and equivalent acceptable material of the driveway culvert, and intermediate manholes adequate for clean-out purposes may be required where the total culvert length exceeds 100 feet. 
c.  Where no side ditch separates the restricted area from the roadbed, permanent provision may be required to separate the area from the highway roadbed to prevent its use for driveway or parking purposes by construction of a boarder, curb, rail, or posts deemed adequate by the zoning administrator. 
(b)  General design standards. The location, design, and construction of the driveway shall be in accordance with the following standards. Additional access improvements such as, but not limited to, deceleration lanes, dedicated left-turning lanes, center turn lanes, merge lanes, and signalization may be required for safe traffic operations, if deemed necessary by the city engineer. 
(1)  A driveway shall be located and restricted as to width as necessary so that the entire driveway and its appurtenances are contained within the frontage along the highway of the property served. At public highway intersections a driveway shall not provide direct ingress or egress to or from the public highway intersection area and shall not encroach on or occupy areas of the roadway or right-of-way deemed necessary for effective traffic control or for highway signs or signals. A driveway shall be so located and constructed that vehicles approaching or using it will have adequate sight distance in both directions along the highway. 
(2)  The number of driveways permitted serving a single property frontage shall be a maximum of two unless more are deemed necessary by the zoning administrator for reasonable service to the property without undue impairment of safety, convenience, and utility of the highway. 
(3)  If the property has frontage on more than one street, and a driveway permit is requested, and if it is determined that the construction of such a driveway on the major street would cause a nuisance to the surrounding area, a traffic hazard, or unduly congest traffic, then the permit may be denied. 
(c)  Specific design standards. The following specific design standards shall apply to driveways requiring permits as set forth in these regulations: 
(1)  Driveway widths. 

 
(2)  Driveway angle. 

 
(3)  Return radii. 

 
(4)  Percent of property frontage available for driveways and approaches. Each single driveway shall have a maximum width of 30 percent of the property frontage. Where two or more driveways are permitted, no more than 60 percent of property frontage shall be used as driveways. No approval for a curb cut will be given where it is apparent that the intent is not to provide access but to provide parking only. A driveway approach must provide access to something definite on private property such as parking area considerably greater in extent than the width of the driveway, or provide access to a driveway, or to a door at least eight feet wide intended for the entrance of vehicles, etc. (Not applicable for residential driveways.) 
(5)  Minimum distance to side property lines. The more restrictive of subsection (5)a or (5)b of this section shall apply. 
a.  The area along a side property line within five feet of a frontage boundary line shall be a restricted area on which no driveway may be developed on public right-of-way. 
b.  A minimum of five feet between the side property line and the pavement edge or curb shall be left undisturbed or landscaped adjacent to each frontage boundary lien to serve as an island area. This distance shall be measured between the frontage boundary tangency of the driveway radius and edge of pavement measured along edge of pavement. This distance shall be increased to 25 feet where the subject lot abuts a residential district. 
These requirements may be waived when a single driveway is approved to serve two adjacent lots: (See also section 54-216.) 
(6)  Island areas (channelization). 
a.  Minimum island dimensions. 
1.  Distance between double driveways: ten feet minimum at narrowest point. 
2.  Minimum island depth: ten feet where parking lot abuts street right-of-way line. 
b.  Treatment of island of buffer area. In the development of private property and the construction of driveways thereto, it may be necessary to regrade the buffer area by cutting or filling. Such work shall be done in a manner to ensure adequate sight distance for traffic operations, proper drainage, suitable slopes for maintenance operations, and good appearance. The buffer area outside the driveway shall be designed to ensure no access by vehicles. This may be accomplished by the grading, use of curbs, rails, guide post, low walls, low shrubs, etc., in a manner which will not impair clear sight across the area. 
c.  Visibility clearance. No landscaping, fences, terraces, or other natural or artificial features adjacent to any street shall be of a nature impairing visibility from or of approaching vehicular traffic where such visibility is important to safety, nor shall such features in any way create potential hazards to pedestrians. In particular, at vehicular entrances and exits, no off street parking, landscaping, or other material impediment to visibility between the height of 2.5 feet and 12 feet measured from the roadway level, shall be permitted within triangular areas defined by lines connecting points described as follows: 
1.  Nonresidential use. Beginning at a point where the midline of the entrance or exit intersects the public right-of-way, thence to a point of 35 feet along the right-of-way in the direction of approaching traffic, thence to a point of 25 feet toward the interior of the lot along the midline of the entrance or exit, and thence to a point of beginning. 
2.  Multifamily residential use. Beginning at a point where the midline of the entrance or exit intersects the public right-of-way, thence to a point of ten feet along the right-of-way in the direction approaching traffic, thence to a point of ten feet toward the interior of the lot along the mid-line of the entrance or exit, and thence to point of beginning. (See also section 54-82.) 
(7)  Intersection clearance (corner island channelization). The length, width and shape of corner island areas will vary for different locations. The angle of intersections, angle of driveways, width of the right-of-way on both approaches, channelization radii, and other conditions will influence the location of driveways at intersections. The location and angle of an approach in relation to the highway intersection shall be such that a vehicle leaving the service facility may be merged in a lane of traffic moving in the desired direction before crossing the intersection; and that a vehicle entering the facility from the intersection may do so in an orderly and safe manner with a minimum of interference to through traffic. The following conditions shall be applicable in most instances: 
a.  No driveway shall be allowed to encroach upon pavement edge radii. 
b.  The following minimum distances from the intersection right-of-way line shall apply where there is no conflict with the foregoing conditions: 
1.  Traffic volume Average Daily Traffic (ADT) of 1,500 or less: 20 feet. 
2.  Traffic volume ADT over 1,500 but less than 10,000: 35 feet. 
3.  Traffic volume ADT over 10,000 but less than 15,000: 50 feet. 
4.  Traffic volume ADT over 15,000: 65 feet. 
The zoning administrator shall have the authority to increase these distances if in his opinion such action is necessary to ensure proper circulation of traffic. The zoning administrator may also modify these requirements if justifiable on the basis of site conditions. 
(8)  Parking and storage areas. Each establishment required by the zoning regulations in chapter 54 to have off-street parking, when providing off-street parking or storage space, shall provide such parking or storage space off the right-of-way to prevent the storage of vehicles on the driveway or the backing up of traffic on the travel way. Particular attention will be paid to "drive-in facilities" such as banks, car washes, drive-through restaurants, drive-in bill paying facilities, and other service facilities where motorists are served while in their vehicles, to ensure that queues of vehicles will not extend out onto the public streets. 
(9)  Driveway grade. 
a.  Residential driveways. The maximum grade which shall be permitted is 17 percent. 
b.  Apartments, commercial and industrial driveways. The maximum grade which shall be permitted is eight percent. 
c.  Grades within the right-of-way shall be controlled by existing shoulder slope or existing and future sidewalk elevations. 
d.  When driveways are intended for special use vehicles, the underside clearance and/or break-over angle of the subject vehicle shall dictate the maximum driveway grade. 
(d)  General conditions of approval. The following conditions shall apply to all approvals for driveway construction on public right-of-way. 
(1)  The applicant shall represent all parties with a property interest in the proposed driveway and shall certify that any driveway or approach constructed by him is for the bonafide purpose of securing access to his property and not for the purpose of parking or servicing vehicles, or for advertising, storage, or merchandising of goods on the city right-of-way. 
(2)  The applicant shall furnish all materials, do all work, and pay all costs in connection with the construction and maintenance of the driveway and its appurtenances on the right-of-way unless the city council agrees otherwise. The applicant shall arrange for and bear the entire cost of moving poles, trees, signs, hydrants, catchbasins, and other existing installations which may interfere with the proposed driveway. Materials used and type and character of work shall be suitable and appropriate for its intended purpose, and the type of construction shall be as designated and subject to approval of the zoning administrator. The timetable for installation shall be approved by the zoning administrator. The applicant shall make the installation without jeopardy to or interference with vehicular traffic using the highway or pedestrian traffic using the adjacent sidewalk. Street surfaces, shoulders, ditches, and vegetation disturbed shall be restored to equivalent or original condition by the applicant. 
(3)  No revisions or additions shall be made to the driveway or its appurtenances on the right-of-way without the written permission of the zoning administrator. 
(4)  The city reserves the right to make such changes, additions, repairs and relocations within statutory limits to the driveway or its appurtenances on the right-of-way as may at any time be considered necessary to permit the relocation, reconstruction, widening, and maintaining of the highway or to provide proper protection to life and property on or adjacent to the street. The city shall make all reasonable attempts to comply with all provisions of this chapter. 
(5)  The applicant, his successors or assignees, agree to hold harmless the city and its duly appointed agents and employees against any action for personal injury or property damage sustained by reasons of the exercise of the permit issued pursuant to these regulations. 
(6)  Whenever an existing road is improved by reconstruction or maintenance work, existing entrances to the road may be altered by the city to conform to the spirit and intent of the policy and standards set forth in these regulations. 
(7)  Whenever the zoning administrator determines that inadequate or indiscriminate access or long stretches of paved or unpaved accesses result in an undue hazard to the motoring public on the thoroughfare, existing entrances may be required to be altered or reduced in extent to conform with the spirit and intent of this policy and upon approval of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 221, § 516, 4-11-1994; Ord. No. 2010-CO-11-666, § 13, 12-13-2010) 
Sec. 44-164. - Additional construction specifications. 
For those improvements where construction specifications have not been set forth in this chapter, the city engineer shall determine such specifications, and construction of improvements shall be as required by the city engineer. 
(Ord. No. 221, § 517, 4-11-1994) 
Secs. 44-165—44-192. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - ADMINISTRATIVE AND LEGAL STATUS PROVISIONS 

Sec. 44-193. - Administration and interpretation. 
The zoning administrator shall administer and interpret the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 221, § 601, 4-11-1994) 
Sec. 44-194. - Violation and penalty. 
In any case where any land is, or is proposed to be, used in violation of this chapter, the city attorney may, in addition to other remedies provided by law, institute injunction, abatement, or any appropriate action of actions, or proceeding to prevent, enjoin or abate such unlawful use. 
(Ord. No. 221, § 602, 4-11-1994) 
Sec. 44-195. - Amendment. 
This chapter may be amended. Before enacting such amendment, the city council shall hold a public hearing thereon, notice of which shall be published at least 15 days prior to such hearing in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. 
(Ord. No. 221, § 603, 4-11-1994) 
Sec. 44-196. - Variances. 
The city council may approve variances to the provisions of this chapter, after recommendation by the planning commission and a public hearing before the city council, notice of which shall be published at least 15 days prior to such hearing in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. 
(Ord. No. 221, § 604, 4-11-1994) 
Secs. 44-197—44-215. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - CONSERVATION SUBDIVISIONS 

Sec. 44-216. - Findings. 
It is hereby determined by the city council that conservation subdivisions in residential zones can provide for the preservation of open space and greenspace for watershed protection and the nonstructural management of stormwater runoff. 
(Ord. No. 434, § 101(A), 7-11-2005) 
Sec. 44-217. - Purpose and intent. 
The purpose of this article is to protect the public health, safety, environment and general welfare. The objectives of this article are: 
(1)  To provide for the preservation of greenspace as a nonstructural stormwater runoff and watershed protection measure. 
(2)  To provide a residential zoning district that permits flexibility of design in order to promote environmentally sensitive and efficient uses of the land. 
(3)  To preserve in perpetuity unique or sensitive natural resources such as groundwater, floodplains, wetlands, streams, steep slopes, woodlands and wildlife habitat. 
(4)  To permit clustering of houses and structures on less environmentally sensitive soils that will reduce the amount of infrastructure including paved surfaces and utility easements necessary for residential development. 
(5)  To reduce erosion and sedimentation by minimizing land disturbance and removal of vegetation in residential development. 
(6)  To promote interconnected greenways and corridors throughout the community. 
(7)  To promote contiguous greenspace with adjacent jurisdictions. 
(8)  To encourage interaction in the community by clustering houses and orienting them closer to the street, providing public gathering places and encouraging use of parks and community facilities as focal points in the neighborhood. 
(9)  To encourage street designs which reduce traffic speeds and reliance on main arteries. 
(10)  To promote construction of convenient landscaped walking trails and bike paths both within the subdivision and connected to neighboring communities, businesses and facilities to reduce reliance on automobiles. 
(11)  To conserve scenic views and reduce perceived density by maximizing the number of houses with direct access to and views of open space. 
(12)  To preserve important historic and archaeological sites. 
(Ord. No. 434, § 101(B), 7-11-2005) 
Sec. 44-218. - Applicability; ownership; housing density determination. 
(a)  Applicability of regulations. This conservation subdivision option is available in the R-1, R-2, R-3 and R-4 zoning districts as a use by right. The applicant shall comply with all other provisions of chapter 54, zoning, and all other applicable laws except those that are incompatible with the provisions contained herein. 
(b)  Ownership of development site. The tract of land to be subdivided may be held in single and separate ownership or in multiple ownership. If held in multiple ownership, however, the site shall be developed according to a single plan with common authority and common responsibility. 
(c)  Housing density determination. The maximum number of lots in the conservation subdivision shall be determined by either of the following two methods at the discretion of the local jurisdiction: 
(1)  Calculation. The maximum number of lots is determined by dividing the area of the tract of land by the minimum lot size specified in the underlying zoning. In making this calculation, the following shall not be included in the total area of the parcel: 
a.  Slopes over 25 percent of at least 5,000 square feet contiguous area; 
b.  The 100-year floodplain; 
c.  Bodies of open water over 5,000 square feet contiguous area; 
d.  Wetlands that meet the definition of the Army Corps of Engineers pursuant to the Clean Water Act; or 
e.  Anticipated right-of-way needs for roads and utilities. 
(2)  Yield. The maximum number of lots is based on a conventional subdivision design plan, prepared by the applicant, in which the tract of land is subdivided in a manner intended to yield the highest number of lots possible. The plan does not have to meet formal requirements for a site design plan, but the design must be capable of being constructed given site features and all applicable regulations. 
(Ord. No. 434, § 201, 7-11-2005) 
Sec. 44-219. - Application requirements. 
(a)  Site analysis map required. Concurrent with the submission of a site concept plan, applicant shall prepare and submit a site analysis map. The purpose of the site analysis map is to ensure that the important site features have been adequately identified prior to the creation of the site design and that the proposed open space will meet the requirements of this article. The preliminary site plan shall include the following features: 
(1)  Property boundaries; 
(2)  All streams, rivers, lakes, wetlands and other hydrologic features; 
(3)  Topographic contours of no less than ten-foot intervals; 
(4)  All primary and secondary conservation areas labeled by type as described in section 44-220; 
(5)  General vegetation characteristics; 
(6)  General soil types; 
(7)  The planned location of protected open space; 
(8)  Existing roads and structures; and 
(9)  Potential connections with existing greenspace and trails. 
(b)  Open space management plan required. An open space management plan as described in section 44-220 shall be prepared and submitted prior to the issuance of a land disturbance permit. 
(c)  Instrument of permanent protection required. An instrument of permanent protection such as a conservation easement or permanent restrictive covenant and as described in section 44-220 shall be placed on the open space concurrent with the issuance of a land disturbance permit. 
(d)  Other requirements. The applicant shall adhere to all other applicable requirements of the underlying zoning and the subdivision and land development regulations of the city. 
(Ord. No. 434, § 301, 7-11-2005) 
Sec. 44-220. - Open space. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Open space means the portion of the conservation subdivision that has been set aside for permanent protection. Activities within the open space are restricted in perpetuity through the use of an approved legal instrument. 
(b)  Standards to determine open space. 
(1)  The minimum restricted open space shall comprise at least 40 percent of the gross tract area. 
(2)  The following are considered primary conservation areas and are required to be included within the open space unless the applicant demonstrates that this provision would constitute an unusual hardship and be counter to the purposes of this article: 
a.  The regulatory 100-year floodplain; 
b.  Buffer zones of at least 75 feet wide along all perennial and intermittent streams; 
c.  Slopes above 25 percent of at least 5,000 square feet contiguous area; 
d.  Wetlands that meet the definition used by the Army Corps of Engineers pursuant to the Clean Water Act; 
e.  Populations of endangered or threatened species or habitat for such species; and 
f.  Archaeological sites, cemeteries and burial grounds. 
(3)  The following are considered secondary conservation areas and should be included within the open space to the maximum extent feasible. 
a.  Important historic sites; 
b.  Existing healthy, native forests of at least one acre contiguous area; 
c.  Individual existing healthy trees greater than eight inches caliper as measured from their outermost drip line; 
d.  Other significant natural features and scenic views such as ridge lines, peaks and rock outcroppings, particularly those that can be seen from public roads; 
e.  Prime agricultural lands of at least five acres contiguous area; and 
f.  Existing trails that connect the tract to neighboring areas. 
(4)  Aboveground utility rights-of-way and small areas of impervious surface may be included within the protected open space but cannot be counted towards the 40 percent minimum area requirement (exception: historic structures and existing trails may be counted). Large areas of impervious surface shall be excluded from the open space. 
(5)  At least 75 percent of the open space shall be in a contiguous tract. The open space should adjoin any neighboring areas of open space, other protected areas, and nonprotected natural areas that would be candidates for inclusion as part of a future area of protected open space. 
(6)  The open space shall be directly accessible to the largest practicable number of lots within the subdivision. Nonadjoining lots shall be provided with safe, convenient access to the open space. 
(c)  Permitted uses of open space. Uses of open space may include the following: 
(1)  Conservation of natural, archeological or historical resources; 
(2)  Meadows, woodlands, wetlands, wildlife corridors, game preserves or similar conservation-oriented areas; 
(3)  Walking or bicycle trails provided they are constructed of porous paving materials; 
(4)  Passive recreation areas; 
(5)  Active recreation areas provided that they are limited to no more than ten percent of the total open space and are not located within primary conservation areas. Active recreation areas may include impervious surfaces. Active recreation areas in excess of this limit must be located outside of the protected open space; 
(6)  Agriculture, horticulture, silviculture or pasture uses provided that all applicable best management practices are used to minimize environmental impacts, and such activities are not conducted within primary conservation areas; 
(7)  Nonstructural stormwater management practices; 
(8)  Easements for drainage, access, and underground utility lines; or 
(9)  Other conservation-oriented uses compatible with the purposes of this article. 
(d)  Prohibited uses of open space. 
(1)  Golf courses;
